head.headtext: Types of Fiduciary Duties Owed—Solicitor Client Relationships

para.paratext: In the leading case of MacDonald Estate v. Martin[1] the Supreme Court of Canada recognized the importance of solicitor client confidence to the integrity of the justice system, confidence of a litigant and concern that a litigant should not be deprived of counsel without good cause.[2]

The law of conflicts was considered by the Supreme Court of Canada in Wallace v. Canadian Pacific Railway[3] where the court observed that the law is mainly concerned with two types of prejudice: prejudice arising as a result of a solicitor's misuse of confidential information obtained from a client and prejudice arising where a solicitor “soft peddles” his representation of a client in order to serve his own interests, those of another client, or those of a third person. The solicitor's main duty to a former client is to refrain from misusing confidential information. With respect to a current client, the solicitor must not misuse confidential information or place himself in a situation that jeopardizes effective representation.[4]

The duty to avoid conflicts reinforces the lawyer's distinct duty of confidentiality by preventing situations that carry a heightened risk of a breach of confidentiality. A lawyer cannot act in a matter where he may use confidential information obtained from a former or current client to the detriment of that client. The two-part test formulated in MacDonald Estate v. Martin[5] is applied to determine whether the new matter will place the lawyer in a conflict of interest: (1) Did the lawyer receive confidential information attributable to a solicitor and client relationship relevant to the matter at hand?[6] (2) Is there a risk that it will be used to the prejudice of that client. If the lawyer's new retainer is “sufficiently related” to the matters on which he or she worked for the former client, a rebuttable presumption arises that the lawyer possesses confidential information that raises a risk of prejudice.[7]

The Canadian National Railway Company retained the law firm to act for it on a variety of matters. In late 2008, the law firm was acting for CN on three ongoing matters. As well, two of its partners held power of attorney from CN for service of process in Saskatchewan. At the same time, the law firm accepted a retainer from Gordon Wallace to act against CN in a $1.75 billion class action based on allegations that CN had illegally overcharged Western Canadian farmers for grain transportation. The Wallace action was legally and factually unrelated to the ongoing CN retainers. The law firm did not advise CN that it intended to accept the Wallace retainer.[8] The Chief Justice concluded that the law firm's concurrent representation of CN and Wallace fell squarely within the scope of the bright line rule. CN and Wallace were adverse in legal interests. CN had not attempted to tactically abuse the bright line rule; and it was reasonable in the circumstances for CN to expect that the law firm would not concurrently represent a party suing it for $1.75 billion. The law firm failed to obtain CN's consent to the concurrent representation of Wallace, and consequently breached the bright line rule when it accepted the Wallace retainer.[9]

However, this was not a situation where there also existed a risk of misuse of confidential information. CN's contention that the law firm obtained confidential information that might assist it on the Wallace matter, namely, a general understanding of CN's litigation philosophy, did not withstand scrutiny. The real estate, insolvency, and personal injury files on which the law firm worked were entirely unrelated to the Wallace action, and CN failed to show how they or other matters on which the law firm acted could have yielded relevant confidential information that could be used against it.[10]

In Abt v. Abt,[11] an application by the wife for an order for the removal of the husband's counsel of record alleging that had has received her confidential information from a legal assistant and was therefore in a conflict of interest was dismissed.[12]

The wife retained the services of her original lawyer to represent her in divorce and matrimonial property proceedings. Her original lawyer was appointed a judge of the Provincial Court and conduct of the wife's file was assumed by her current counsel. The original lawyer's legal assistant during the approximately 15 months he represented the wife had direct involvement with the conduct of the wife's file and direct communications with the wife. After the transition of the wife's file, the legal assistant had minimal and then eventually no further involvement, although she continued to work for the firm until her departure in October, 2018. The legal assistant was recently employed by the husband's lawyer as a legal assistant for a period of three weeks, during which time the legal assistant had direct involvement with the husband's file. The legal assistant acknowledged that during the original lawyer's representation of the wife that she would have handled file correspondence and relayed information between lawyer and client. She deposed that she did not recall any details or information about the wife's file from that employment. She further swore that she did not at any time discuss her previous involvement with the file with the husband's lawyer because she had no memory of it, and that the husband's lawyer did not ever ask her about it.[13]

The husband's lawyer submitted that the application was tactical as the husband would be deprived of counsel of choice in a critical phase of the proceedings. There were imminent deadlines existing for examinations and undertakings in preparation for a scheduled trial.[14]

Justice Slawinsky reviewed the law governing mobility of legal assistants as set out in Chern v. Chern, 2006 ABCA 16, wherein the Court of Appeal observed that the correct legal test to be used was the one set out by the Supreme Court of Canada in MacDonald Estate stating:

17 Although MacDonald Estate dealt with the situation where a lawyer changed firms, the Ontario Court of Appeal has held that the same considerations apply to “non-professional” employees such as legal assistants: Hildinger v. Carroll, [2004] O.J. No. 291 (Ont. C.A.).

There was no dispute that the legal assistant would have been aware of confidential information concerning the wife, satisfying the first step in the test in MacDonald Estate v. Martin [1990 CarswellMan 384 (S.C.C.)]. The dispute centered around the second step, namely whether there was a risk that this confidential information would be used to the prejudice of the wife. Justice Slawinsky observed that, according to MacDonald Estate, it is presumed that any confidential information received by the legal assistant in her work on the file would be shared in her new role with the husband's lawyer, “unless it can be shown using ‘clear and convincing evidence’ that institutional measures had been taken to ensure that it did not”. The burden of proof in this regard was on the husband.[15]

The affidavits sworn by the legal assistant to support the husband's challenge to this rebuttable presumption did not speak to the existence of effective institutional screening measures, but did specifically address whether the legal assistant actually communicated any information concerning the wife to the husband's lawyer during her brief employment with him. The legal assistant swore that she had no memory of the file and was not involved with it for nearly five years following the original lawyer's appointment to the bench and prior to joining the firm of the husband's lawyer. She further swore that she had not at any time discussed with the husband's lawyer her knowledge of the file gained during her previous employment, and that the husband's lawyer had not asked. That evidence was uncontradicted, and confirmed by the husband's lawyer's representations as an officer of the court. Justice Slawinsky concluded as a fact that no confidential information was conveyed.[16]

Justice Slawinsky explained that the Court must balance confidence in the integrity of the justice system to safeguard information imparted to counsel and staff with the husband's constitutionally entrenched right to counsel and the need to reasonably facilitate mobility in the legal profession. Applying MacDonald Estate and Chern, Justice Slawinsky was satisfied the presumption that confidential information was shared with the husband's lawyer or his client through the legal assistant had been rebutted by her lack of recollection of the file and her clear testimony that she has had no such conversations with the husband's lawyer. Justice Slawinsky inferred from her lack of memory of the file that she had also not shared any information directly with the husband. In addition, Justice Slawinsky took into account the length of time since the legal assistant was involved with the file at the law firm representing the wife, the length of time between the conclusion of her employment there prior to the commencement of her employment with the husband's lawyer, the length of her employment with the husband's lawyer, and the fact that she was no longer employed with him. In all of the circumstances, the likelihood of risk of prejudice to the wife was minimal or nonexistent and a reasonable person, fully informed of the facts, would concur. The facts did not warrant the removal of the husband's lawyer as counsel for the husband.[17]

The Applicants motion to have the solicitor of record for the Respondents, in two related applications known as the Lease Application and the Governance Application, disqualified and removed in both applications was dismissed in Bose v. Bangiya Parishad Toronto.[18]

Until recently, the Cultural Association and the Congregation operated as a unity. The Cultural Organization was properly organized as a corporation, but the Congregation was not. However, members of the Cultural Association were de facto members of the Congregation, which technically did not enroll its members or organize its corporate affairs as did the Cultural Association. The By-laws for the Cultural Association were adopted in 1987. Up until June 2016, the by-laws do not mention being applicable to the Congregation. Since 1980, the members of the Cultural Association, who are the de facto members of the Congregation, have elected a common board of directors. The members of the Cultural Association also elected the presidents of both corporations. The common Board of Directors would then appoint from the Board Members the officers for the two corporations. They produced consolidated financial statements for the cultural organization and for the religious organization. The Congregation was the registered owner of a property known the Tagore Centre. The Tagore Centre had originally been purchased by the Cultural Association in 1987, but in 1992, the property was transferred to the Congregation to benefit from its charitable status. It was alleged that pursuant to a two-page lease dated February 6, 1995, the Congregation leased part of the Tagore Centre to the Cultural Association. There was no rent charge. In the Lease Application, the Respondents disputed that the Lease actually existed and challenged whether it was enforceable. Up until the corporate internecine conflict, the Cultural Association and the Congregation peacefully shared the Tagore Centre.[19]

On April 11, 2016, the members of the Cultural Association elected eleven Directors. Ghose was elected to be the President of the Cultural Association and Chowdhury was elected to be the President of the Congregation. For the Cultural Association, the Directors elected Ghose's slate of officers. Internecine conflict then erupted about the election of officers for the Congregation. Ghose and a majority of directors opposed the slate of officers for the Congregation that had been selected by Chowdhury. As a result of the dispute, Chowdhury and a minority group of Directors protested. By June 2016, they organized a membership enrollment for the Congregation, nullified the election of directors for the Congregation, and formed a new Board of Directors. They were elected directors. The actions by Chowdhury and his allies had the result of establishing the de facto Congregation.[20]

One or the other of Chowdhury's group spoke to lawyers. Ultimately, Chowdhury hired the solicitor to act for the de facto Congregation. The solicitor began providing the de facto Congregation with legal advice in the internecine corporate warfare between the not-for-profit organizations. The solicitor's client was the de facto Corporation, not the directors of the de facto corporation.[21]

By June of 2016, there were rival Boards of Directors and rival religious organizations. Who, how, and what was the de jure or lawful Congregation was uncertain. The board of the de facto Congregation began purporting to govern the Congregation, independently from the Cultural Association. The religious organization was being run by the group that were later to become Respondents in the two applications before the court; the Lease Application and the Governance Application. The de facto Congregation instructed the solicitor to take steps to separate the de facto Congregation's governance from the governance of the Cultural Association.[22]

Ghose and his allies at the Cultural Association opposed the activities of the new board of directors of the de facto Congregation, and in June of 2016, members of the Cultural Association circulated a petition calling for Chowdhury to resign as a Director, which he refused to do. With Chowdhury refusing to resign, the Cultural Association responded by calling an extraordinary general meeting of its membership to be held at the Tagore Centre on July 17, 2016. One purpose of the meeting was to have Chowdhury removed as a Director. The Cultural Association was now making a counterattack to regain governance of the Congregation.[23]

On June 20, 2016, introducing himself as retained by the de facto Congregation, the solicitor wrote to Ghose to respond to an email message that Ghose had sent to Mr. Chowdhury. In his letter to Ghose, the solicitor indicated that the Congregation was distinct from the Cultural Association, since they were separate legal entities. He stated that the Cultural Association could not impose its by-laws and dictate terms to the Congregation. He stated that any attempts to disrupt the democratic function of the Congregation would be vigorously answered. He urged Ghose to come to a negotiated settlement.[24]

Chowdhury's group continued in the effort to separate the corporate affairs of the Congregation from the affairs of the Cultural Association. At a meeting of the de facto Congregation on July 10, 2016, an elections officer was appointed, the Board of Directors of the April-Congregation were removed and a new Board of Directors was elected.[25]

Ghose and Mukherjee arrived uninvited at the July 10, 2016 meeting to object to the activities of the de facto Congregation and to warn of consequences. The next day, the Board of Directors of the April-Congregation passed a resolution that the solicitor was not authorized to represent the interests of the Congregation. Alarmed by Ghose's threat about changing the locks, Chowdhury as president of the de facto Congregation responded by instructing the solicitor to retain a bailiff to take the upper hand on controlling access to the Tagore Centre. The solicitor retained bailiffs and on July 14, 2016, the locks at the Tagore Centre were changed by the bailiff. Unable to enter the Tagore Centre on July 17, 2016, the members of the Cultural Association went to another location, and they passed a resolution that Chowdhury should be removed as a director.[26]

The lockout of the Tagore Centre persisted, but despite negotiations, the dispute could not be resolved, and over a year later, on August 11, 2017, several members of the Cultural Association decided not to wait for the Cultural Association to sort out the governance problems. Thus, an application was commenced pursuant to s. 332 of the Corporations Act to regain access to the Tagore Centre. This Application was known as the Lease Application. The Applicants in the Lease Application sued the de facto Congregation. The Applicants relied on the 1995 Lease Agreement.[27]

The dispute about the governance of the Congregation remained unresolved. The Cultural Association did not accept the de facto Congregation as having a lawfully elected Board of Directors. The Cultural Association finally decided to commence proceedings to resolve who governed the Congregation. The purpose of the application, known as the Governance Application, was to resolve who were the lawful Directors of the Congregation and what was the genuine Congregation. The solicitor was the lawyer of record of all of the Respondents with the exception of Mukherjee and Banerjee. The de facto Congregation was not a respondent to the Governance Application.[28]

At this juncture, the solicitor had a joint retainer for the de facto Congregation and for the Respondents in their personal capacity as directors of the de facto Congregation. The solicitor did not have a retainer from Banerjee, who had been a director of the de facto Corporation.[29]

The proposed timetable included an examination of Banerjee. Banerjee was a Respondent to the Governance Application, but he had not entered an appearance. He was not represented by the solicitor. Banerjee was disassociating himself from the de facto Congregation.[30]

On June 18, 2018, pursuant to a summons served by the Applicants in the Governance Application, Banerjee was examined as a witness at a special examiner's office. Before the examination, Banerjee, who was a self-represented Respondent in the Governance Application, was interviewed by counsel for the Applicants in the Governance Application.[31]

The solicitor also cross-examined Banerjee. During the cross-examination, they engaged in a heated and acrimonious argument. During his cross-examination, Banerjee testified that Chowdhury had retained the solicitor for the de facto Congregation and that the solicitor had advised them to separate the Congregation and the Cultural Association into separate legal entities, including creating a separate membership list for the Congregation. Banerjee testified that it was the solicitor that prepared a by-law for the de facto Congregation. The Applicants submitted that it was Banerjee's cross-examination that revealed to them that the solicitor had disqualifying conflicts of interest.[32]

A lawyer may be disqualified from representing a party, if the lawyer has a conflict of interest. There are many different types of conflict of interest. Conflicts of interest may arise, among other situations: (a) when a lawyer acts for more than one client in a multiple retainer; (b) when a lawyer is retained on a matter that involves acting against a former client; (c) when a lawyer with knowledge of a client's legal affairs changes law firms and joins a law firm acting against the former client; (d) when a lawyer accepts a retainer against a former client of the law firm in a matter related to a previous retainer; and (e) when a lawyer is in a position of having to give significant or controversial evidence in a case in which he or she or an associate is acting as counsel.[33]

The determination of whether a lawyer should be disqualified is very fact specific and based on an examination of all of the factors in the case including the motivation for the motion; the task of the court is to uphold and preserve the integrity of the justice system while ensuring that litigants are not deprived of their counsel of choice without good cause. Although the right to one's choice of counsel is one of the values identified in MacDonald Estate as bearing on the issue of whether there is disqualifying conflict, primacy is given to ensuring the integrity of both the legal profession and the administration of justice.[34]

Justice Perell observed that another variety of conflict of interest is the conflict of acting as both counsel and as a witness in the client's litigation. An advocate cannot be a substantive witness in his or her client's litigation because as an advocate, he or she has a duty to the administration of justice to be objective and detached from the client's litigation which duty could conflict with the advocate's duty to present the client's case in as favourable a light as possible. If it is clear from the outset of a proceeding or if it becomes clear during the proceeding that the advocate will be a material witness, he or she should be disqualified and removed as lawyer of record. The disqualification arises even if counsel does not intend to testify because his or her involvement in the matter based on participation and actual knowledge of the events rather than based on just taking instructions from his client creates a conflict between his or her duty to the court and his or her duty to the client.[35]

If there is only a potential that the advocate will have substantive evidence and be a witness for his or her client, then on a motion to have the lawyer disqualified, the court considers a number of factors in determining whether to disqualify the lawyer including: (a) how likely the lawyer will be a witness; (b) the materiality and significance of the lawyer's evidence; (c) the likelihood of a real conflict or that the evidence will be tainted; (d) the stage of the proceedings; (e) the timeliness of the motion; (f) the impact of removal of counsel on his or her client's right to be represented by counsel of choice; and (g) the good faith of the party making the application; (h) the mode of trial, whether judge alone or judge and jury; (i) who will call the counsel as witness; and (j) the current and past relationship between counsel and the parties involved in the litigation.[36]

While it is not necessary for the moving party to show that counsel will certainly be a material witness, conversely it is not sufficient for disqualification that the moving party can just show that counsel is a potential witness or that counsel might provide some material evidence. Where neither party has indicated a clear intention to call the lawyer as a witness, the disqualification motion is premature, although the issue of disqualification can be revisited later if the likelihood of testifying changes.[37]

Justice Perell disagreed with the Applicants' argument that the solicitor should be disqualified because he was a potential witness. In Justice Perell's opinion, the solicitor was not a witness nor was he a participant in the events, only some of which he observed. Clients regularly act on the advice of their lawyers and should the client's conduct lead to litigation, his or her lawyer's involvement in the matter does not necessarily disqualify the lawyer from continued involvement in the litigation.[38]

The solicitor had nothing material to say about the events of April 2016 that precipitated the internecine warfare between the Cultural Association and the de facto Congregation because he was not retained as the lawyer of the de facto Congregation until June 2016 when he took instructions about the history of the matter. The solicitor was hired as a lawyer for the de facto Congregation, and he gave his client legal advice. He wrote letters, which spoke for themselves, on the instructions of his client. It was his client that was the actor in the events, not the solicitor. The only evidence that the solicitor could give was about his legal advice to his client, but that advice was privileged, and it is not the solicitor's privilege to waive. If he was subpoenaed to give evidence, the subpoena would be quashed.[39]

The solicitor's involvement in the events leading up to the Lease Application and the Governance Application did not stray from his role as a lawyer for the de facto Congregation. Justice Perell saw no reason why the solicitor would testify or need to testify for the Respondents in either application.[40]

The solicitor did not have a conflict of interest and the principles of the MacDonald Estate v. Martin and the R. v. Neil line of cases did not apply. This was not a situation where the solicitor had a conflict in acting for the corporation and for the majority faction of directors or owners of the corporation. Rather, the solicitor had a joint retainer for the de facto Congregation and for the personal respondents of which there was a common interest to resist the attacks being made by the Applicants to whom the solicitor never had any lawyer-client relationship. Banerjee might have now allied himself with the April-Congregation, but. Banerjee was not a client of the solicitor.[41]

Justice Perell observed that there is no prohibition in having a joint retainer nor a conflict of interest providing that the Law Society's Rules of Professional Conduct that govern joint retainers are complied with. At this juncture of the proceeding, there was no conflict of interest amongst the clients that actually comprised the joint retainer. All the respondents had the common interest of successfully resisting both applications. In acting for the de facto Congregation, the solicitor had no conflict with the Cultural Association or with the April-Congregation because they never were his clients.[42]

A motion by the husband for an order that the law firm be removed as counsel for the wife was allowed in Fahlman v. Fahlman.[43] Justice Layh concluded that the law was in a conflict of interest with the husband, having previously represented the husband on a matter that bore relevance to the litigation at hand.[44]

The husband and wife permanently separated on August 6, 2018. On April 29, 2016, the couple were in an altercation involving a firearm that resulted in the husband's arrest and detention. He was charged with assault pursuant to s. 266 of the Criminal Code. He was released on April 30, 2016 under a peace bond. The husband retained the solicitor. They first spoke on May 2, 2016. The husband characterized the conversation as “a lengthy initial telephone meeting.” During the week of May 2, 2016, the husband and the solicitor had “many phone calls and messages” because they were attempting to have the peace bond restrictions removed. The husband and the solicitor spoke on “multiple occasions in the first week until the no-contact conditions were removed.” The solicitor acted as a “go-between” with the husband and wife. After the week of May 2, 2016, the husband met in person with the solicitor at his law firm where they spoke “at length” about the wife and his past and present relationship with her.[45]

The solicitor differed in his recounting of what was discussed. He stated that his file notes indicated that there was no discussion about the husband's relationship with his spouse in the past or present. Further, there were no conversations concerning the husband's marriage, life at home, parenting their one child or their sexual relations. The solicitor stated there was no need for any of these matters to be discussed because the charges included assault, possession of a weapon dangerous to the public peace and careless use of a fireman. Following the meeting, the solicitor wrote the Yorkton Prosecution Unit requesting disclosure. The husband called upon another lawyer in the firm on May 4, 2016 to determine how the “no-contact” clauses could be deleted. On May 5, 2016, the solicitor had telephone conversations with the Crown, the wife and the husband. His file revealed that there was no discussion with the husband respecting those matters the husband stated were discussed.[46]

On May 30, 2016, the solicitor appeared in court on behalf of the husband to adjourn the matter. On June 15, 2016, the husband again attended his office to discuss sentencing options. The solicitor repeated that he had no discussion about those matters the husband now alleged. On June 27, the solicitor appeared in court where he and the Crown provided a joint submission which resulted in the husband receiving a conditional discharge.[47]

Two years later, during an argument between the couple in June 2018, the wife told her husband that she would be retaining the solicitor against him. The solicitor provided correspondence to the husband stating that the two matters were unrelated and he was not in a conflict of interest.[48]

The husband issued a petition on August 20, 2018, just two weeks after separation. In the petition he claimed divorce, custody, spousal support, child support, exclusive possession of the family home, and division of family property. He immediately brought an application seeking interim joint custody and shared parenting. The husband's initial affidavit in support of his application did not mention anything about the April 2016 charge. The wife swore an affidavit in response. The wife described recent incidents that, if true, would constitute common assault. The wife also described physical aggression not only toward her, but towards their four-year-old daughter. The wife provided a detailed description of the April 2016 incident that led to the husband's charges and his eventual retention of the solicitor as his counsel.[49]

Justice Layh observed that in this instance, the salient question was whether the current conflict between the husband and wife was a fresh and independent matter wholly unrelated to any work the solicitor had previously done for the husband and, if so, whether any previously obtained confidential information was irrelevant to that matter. Justice Layh concluded that the current issues in dispute were neither “independent,” nor “irrelevant” to the issues at hand in the family law matter. The wife's affidavit sworn in response to the husband's application for joint custody of the children, leaned heavily on adverse conclusions she wished the court to draw from the April 29, 2016 incident. If the April 29, 2016 incident were “independent” of the husband's application for joint custody, the wife would have seen no reason to mention it. And, respecting “relevance”, the court accepted that when drafting an affidavit, legal counsel is the gatekeeper of what averments are legally relevant to the issues at hand. That assessment must have been made by the solicitor or some member of the law firm.[50]

In Justice Layh's view, the husband had discharged his obligation to show that the solicitor's continued representation and duties toward the wife necessarily raised a genuine and serious risk of the duty of loyalty toward him. Although the solicitor disavowed discussing with the husband anything about the husband's marriage, life at home, parenting or sexual relations, the court was minimally aware that the solicitor negotiated removal of conditions of the peace bond. He also received letters of reference from unnamed persons, which reasonably would have offered opinions of the husband's history and character. He negotiated a guilty plea of common assault in face of charges involving firearms and successfully obtained a conditional discharge for the husband. The solicitor could only have successfully dealt with these charges by gaining some information about the relationship and by providing some measure of assurance to the Crown and court that the husband did not present unacceptable dangers to the wife and the children.[51]

Justice Layh accepted the three-step direction stated in International Capital Corp. v. Schafer, 1996 CarswellSask 802 (Sask. Q.B.), modelled on MacDonald Estate v. Martin, [1990] 3 S.C.R. 1235, 1990 CarswellMan 384 (S.C.C.):

It is clear that before the first question can be answered in the affirmative, three factors must be established by the applicant: fist, that there was a solicitor and client relationship between the applicant and the lawyer. Second, that the previous relationship is sufficiently related to the retainer from which it is sought to remove the solicitor. Third, that the lawyer received confidential information through the previous relationship. The applicant must prove each of the first and second factors in the usual manner, but once this has been done, proof of the third factor is presumed by means of a rebuttable presumption that confidential information was in fact imparted. Unless the solicitor satisfies the court that no information was imparted which could be relevant, it is presumed that confidential information was imparted. The presumption is a difficult burden to discharge.[52]

Justice Layh disagreed that it was the second step that had not been proven. The solicitor had maintained that his April 2016 relationship with the husband was not related to the matters in question in the current proceedings. The wife's detailed description of the April 29, 2016 incident was not tangential to the points she wished to make in opposition to the husband's application seeking interim shared parenting. Her affidavit offered a focused and highly detailed account of the incident, an account she obviously thought was influential in opposing the husband's application. The circumstances leading to the husband's criminal charges were the same circumstances that the wife clearly thought were relevant to the court's consideration that the parenting relief the husband was seeking was not in the best interests of the children. The wife's recounting of the April 29, 2016 incident revealed conduct that she understandably and reasonably wanted before the court because such conduct would resonate with the court concerning the husband's ability to parent the children. Justice Layh raised no criticism against the wife for advising the court of this incident because it revealed conduct that a court would ordinarily consider in determining parenting skills. The question was whether the solicitor's representing the husband respecting charges arising from this incident was an “independent” and “irrelevant” matter in the family law proceedings. Justice Layh concluded that they were not.[53]

Justice Layh accepted that the Court must consider not only the husband's interests in the application, but also the wife's right to retain counsel of her choice. In MacDonald the Supreme Court of Canada stated “that a litigant should not be deprived of his or her choice of counsel without good cause.” However, that right must be balanced against another person's right to expect a duty of loyalty from his lawyer and the lawyer's duty to maintain the standards of the legal profession and the integrity of the system of justice.[54]

Justice Layh considered the deprivation to the wife if the law firm could not act on her behalf. In the balancing of the interests at stake, the court took judicial notice that other law firms were available to the wife.[55]

In Justice Layh's view, a reasonable member of the public would conclude that if the wife believed that the events of April 26, 2016 were significant in the family law proceedings, then, necessarily, the husband's confidential disclosure of those same events, as he told them to the solicitor, should not be available to the solicitor when representing the wife. If the matter proceeded to trial and if the wife continued her position that the incident of April 26, 2016 was relevant, the husband would have the awkward, and in the court's view, impermissible, obligation to answer questions the solicitor might pose in cross-examination.[56]

The solicitor submitted that the husband could not make bald assertions of the nature of the confidential information he allegedly gave to the solicitor and that more specifics of the confidential information were required. Justice Layh recognized that the husband sought legal advice in face of a charge of domestic violence against his pregnant wife, use of a firearm, a failing marriage, and allegations of drunkenness. These were circumstances of a serious and highly personal nature. The court could not expect the husband to disclose details of confidential matters he necessarily wished to keep confidential. To provide the Court with the details of information he stated he offered in confidence to the solicitor would undermine his expectation of confidentiality. The husband established that a solicitor and client relationship existed arising from the April 29, 2016 incident. He had also proven that the substance of that relationship was “sufficiently related” to the solicitor's current retainer with the wife. With respect to the third step in Schafer—whether the solicitor had rebutted the presumption that confidential information was imparted, Justice Layh concluded that the burden had not been discharged.[57]

An application by the Plaintiffs, brothers Alex and Sam, for an order disqualifying the law firm and a partner in the firm, from acting for the Defendant, their uncle, in the context of a real estate dispute, was dismissed in D'Amico v. D'Amico.[58] The application alleged that the solicitor had acted for different family members in the past, in real estate and other matters, and for Alex in the context of his divorce.[59]

The Introductory Application of Alex and Sam alleged fraudulent behavior of the Defendant in the context of various transfers of an immovable property. The fraudulent transfer took place in April 2011. The lot was originally held in co-ownership by the Plaintiffs' father and their uncle. Upon the passing of their father in 2006, Alex and Sam inherited his share and were therefore in undivided co-ownership with their uncle. The Property was being offered for sale at that time and the parties agreed that the sale process should continue. Given that there was no sale, on September 29, 2009, Plaintiffs agreed to engage in a process with the CPTAQ to subdivide the Property. The agricultural portion of the land would have been sold to the Defendant's son. This process did not prove fruitful. However, seemingly without the approval of the CPTAQ, the parties reached an agreement on February 9, 2011 which divided the Property into two lots, lot 1 and lot 2, each with a cadastral number. The agreement attributed a value of $100,000 to the Property as a whole $30,000 to lot 1 and $70,000 to lot 2. Lot 1 was ceded to Plaintiffs and lot 2 to Defendant. In April 2011, the Defendant sold his lot to a third party for $275,000 and it was that transaction which Plaintiffs alleged gave rise to a fraud.[60]

The Plaintiffs allege numerous files where either the solicitor or the law firm had acted for various family members. In 2005, the solicitor acted for Plaintiffs' father in the context of his divorce proceedings wherein the financing of the Property was discussed with the Defendant's lawyer at the time, the alternative being to terminate the undivided co-ownership. This discussion ended in 2005 and an agreement was entered into between the father and the uncle on November 16, 2005 regarding the modalities of the sale of the Property. The Plaintiffs acknowledged that the solicitor's mandate was with their father, but alleged that the confidential information directly related to the current dispute would have been passed to him at the time and that they would have participated in the passing of this information. The Plaintiffs also alleged that the solicitor acted in their father's divorce in 2005 and 2006, in the father's succession, hence on behalf of them as liquidators of the succession in 2006, and finally the law firm and the solicitor represented Alex in his divorce in 2012, but had their mandate revoked in August 2013. The Plaintiffs alleged that the law firm and the solicitor had access to the personal life of Alex, including his personality traits, his psychological traits and his emotional attitudes. Further, the solicitor through the different matters, had allegedly mastered the culture and family dynamics of the entire family.[61]

The Plaintiffs would have assisted their father in his dispute over the Property with their uncle prior to the 2005 agreement. It was acknowledged that the agreement was concluded on November 16, 2005. This was the last implication of the solicitor in relation to the agreement between his father and uncle for the sale of the Property. Following this agreement, the father passed on June 30, 2006. The solicitor acted for him and his brother in the homologation of the will and provided some advice on the liquidation of the estate. Sam's last contact with the solicitor in respect of the Property was on September 28, 2006 by e-mail where he promised to contact the solicitor if the brothers needed to transfer the Property. Alex confirmed that the solicitor was not involved in the agreements that the Plaintiffs concluded with their uncle on September 28, 2009, on February 9, 2011, and on March 3, 2011. In the context of Alex's divorce, the only issue surrounding the Property was whether his wife would have a claim in his share. He provided the declaration of transmission of the Property prepared by a notary dated November 7, 2008. The solicitor had not been involved in the preparation of this document, but verified the index of immovables to ensure that it had been duly published and upon confirmation of this, advised Alex that his wife would not have a claim. Alex also remitted to the solicitor the deeds of partition as the solicitor wanted to know what had happened to the Property.[62]

The solicitor denied having received further confidential or strategic information about the Property when he prepared the will or when he acted in the homologation proceeding for the father's will. No information regarding the current litigation was ever communicated to him. In Alex's divorce, his only advice in respect of the Property was whether the wife had a claim. His mandate ended in September 2012 when the couple opted for mediation.[63]

The Court observed that unless in the context of his mandates for the father or for the Plaintiffs, the solicitor received or was presumed to have received confidential information that he might use to the prejudice of the Plaintiffs, the Defendant's right to mandate the lawyer of his choice should prevail. The Court observed that, other than Alex in his divorce, the Plaintiffs were never represented by the law firm or the solicitor. At the time of the transactions which gave rise to the current dispute, the solicitor was not acting for them or for Defendant. He had no involvement in the transactions and only became aware of them when Alex provided him with them for the sole purpose of allowing the solicitor to verify whether the wife might have a claim on the Property. Therefore, the duty of commitment rule discussed in McKercher was not fully engaged, as there was no risk of the solicitor terminating a current client to serve a new one. It was fair to say as well, that the rule against the transfer of confidential information was not fully engaged, as in 2005, when the first agreement on the sale of the Property was concluded, the father was the client.[64]

However, the Court explained that it must be cognizant of the important role that the Plaintiffs played in assisting their father at that time and would nonetheless consider whether the inference discussed in Macdonald surrounding the transfer on confidential information applied, assuming for that purpose that the Plaintiffs were the clients of the solicitor. The important strategic information that might have been revealed to the solicitor about the Property in 2005 was not specifically revealed. The 2005 agreement was in relation to the modalities for the sale of the Property. After the signing of that agreement, the solicitor was no longer involved in providing any advice to the Plaintiffs around any issue remotely related to the sale of the Property, even though the intent to sell was still in the minds of Plaintiffs and their uncle following the transfer of the father's interest to the Plaintiffs. If it was the Plaintiffs' or their father's intention to keep the portion of the property with the buildings, there was nothing to suggest that it was imparted to the solicitor. In fact, he was excluded from the future discussions.[65]

The Court concluded that there was no relationship between the 2005 mandate and the current litigation, other than the fact that both related to the Property. In 2005, the agreement was for the sale of the Property. In the current litigation, the Defendant was purported to have committed a fraud, but this was after three agreements designed to allow Plaintiffs to keep the part of the Property with the buildings on it and to transfer the other part to Defendant or his son. Not only would any importance that any strategic family information that the solicitor might have received in 2005 be largely dissipated or without value due to the later agreements, in the Court's view, the presumption that vital information was passed was not engaged, as the required significant relationship between the two matters was not present. As for the homologation proceeding, there was no strategic advice given by the solicitor in relation to the sale of the Property or on ending the undivided co-ownership with Defendant. The same was true of the services rendered in Alex's divorce. There was no compelling reason to remove the flaw firm or the solicitor from the current proceedings.[66]
A motion by the applicant for an order disqualifying a solicitor and the law firm from continuing to act as counsel to the respondent was dismissed in McCain v. Melanson.[67]

The two-step test governing the removal of a lawyer or law firm for breach of a lawyer's duty of confidence: (a) did the lawyer receive confidential information attributable to a solicitor and client relationship relevant to the matter at hand? (b) is there a risk that it will be used to the prejudice of the client applies to circumstances in which the moving party was a client in the course of a solicitor-client relationship and to situations in which the lawyer received relevant confidential information from a non-client. A party seeking to disqualify a law firm from acting on the basis of an alleged breach of confidence should not be required to place the information said to be confidential in the public record. Accordingly, a litigant seeking to disqualify a law firm from acting on the basis of the law firm's possession of relevant confidential information may show one of these two things: (a) that the current retainer and previous retainer are sufficiently related, generating a presumption that the law firm possesses relevant confidential information; or (b) that the law firm actually possesses relevant confidential information. In Celanese Canada Inc. v. Murray Demolition Corp. (2006), 269 D.L.R. (4th) 193, [2006] 2 S.C.R. 189, 215 O.A.C. 266, 30 C.P.C. (6th) 193, 50 C.P.R. (4th) 241, 352 N.R. 1, 2006 CarswellOnt 4623, 2006 CarswellOnt 4624, [2006] S.C.J. No. 35, 2006 SCC 36 (S.C.C.), the Supreme Court addressed the issue as to whether there needed to be a previous solicitor-client relationship in a case in which the two law firms were disqualified from continuing to act on the basis that they had obtained confidential information through the execution of an anton pillar order. The court held that a solicitor-client relationship with the opposing party whose confidential information they had been obtained was not a pre-requisite. The relevant elements of the MacDonald Estate analysis do not depend on a pre-existing solicitor-client relationship. The gravamen of the problem here is the possession by opposing solicitors of relevant and confidential information attributable to a solicitor-client relationship to which they have no claim of right whatsoever. Counsel who seeks to establish a presumption that the applicant gave confidential information bears the onus under the first step of the MacDonald Estate test and must adduce clear and cogent evidence, not mere assertions, to show that a previous retainer is sufficiently related to the current retainer. Furthermore, the moving party must show that the possibility of relevant confidential information having been acquired by the law firm is realistic, not just theoretical. The court must carefully review and compare the retainers to determine whether they are sufficiently related. The moving party must provide evidence of a “sufficient relationship” in which allegedly confidential information obtained by the law firm under the previous retainer could be used against the former client in the current retainer and in some tangible manner.[68]

“Confidential information” is information one would not voluntarily reveal to an opposing lawyer and, in the family law context would extend to the personal habits, faults and foibles of the “client”, knowledge of which might be valuable to the lawyer in the adversarial world of litigation.[69]

Counsel asserted that the applicant had disclosed a considerable amount of personal and confidential information to the solicitor through meetings with therapists, parenting coordinators and mediators. Central to the position taken by the applicant on the disqualification motion was the role of Dr. Weir. In the present proceeding, the respondent pleaded that McCain is a “vengeful, angry person” with “incredible amounts of rage” and that, in light of such allegations, the sensitive personal and confidential information McCain imparted to the solicitor through these meetings was directly relevant. In particular, it was asserted that the hundreds of pages of Dr. Weir's confidential notes could be used against her in this proceeding. The motion judge was not persuaded that the applicant met the onus of establishing that a “sufficient relationship” occurred between the applicant and the solicitor or his firm. First, the legal issues in that earlier proceeding were unrelated to the legal issues in this proceeding: different parties; different legal issues; different factual issues. Second, the central role that the applicant asserted the report(s) of Dr. Weir would take was conjecture or theoretical but not realistic. The motion judge saw no prospect that anything a psychiatrist said over 11 years ago about the applicant's parenting capacity could be relevant to whether she could prove her allegations of misrepresentation and deceit. The fact that Dr. Weir made reference to a personal characteristic such as anger in the context of an assessment did not mean that it was realistic that such references or excerpts from Dr. Weir's notes would be found relevant to the allegations in the answer as to the applicant's anger. Third, it was difficult to accept that the communications she made to other professionals which became known to the solicitor could constitute a “sufficient relationship”. She did not allege that she gave any confidential information to the solicitor; rather, she alleged that what she said to others was communicated to him. The information that she communicated indirectly was not in the category of “confidential information attributable to a solicitor-client relationship to which they have no claim of right whatsoever”. The solicitor had the right to receive the information that he received indirectly. The motion judge did not accept that such information as she communicated to those professionals created an expectation of confidentiality that could be relied upon to disqualify the lawyer for her former spouse from acting for her current spouse.[70]

Counsel for the applicant additionally took the position that the solicitor should be disqualified because he had acted against McCain's brothers in their respective “matrimonial proceedings” in which the solicitors on behalf of each of their spouses, challenged the enforceability of a marriage contract. The motion judge not persuaded that the applicant established that that constituted a special relationship. The applicant was not a party to either of those matters and there was no evidence that she was involved directly or indirectly in either matter. The fact that the enforceability of a marriage contract was in issue in the siblings' cases did not make it similar to proceedings where it was the respondent who sought to enforce the Marriage Agreement while the applicant took the position that it was not enforceable. The applicant provided no evidence as to the extent to which the issues in those matters bore any relationship to the issues in her matter. It might be that as a result of acting for the wives of her two brothers the solicitor received financial information about the siblings that might be related to the Applicant. But that does not meet the burden of “sufficient relationship”.[71]

Counsel concentrated on the submission that the applicant had established a presumption that she gave confidential information to the solicitor during the course of the David v. McCain litigation or the disputes between her brothers and their ex-spouses. Having failed to fulfill the burden of proof of a “sufficient relationship” in respect of any of them, the applicant was not entitled to the benefit of the presumption. There was no evidence that the solicitor actually possessed relevant confidential information and accordingly the motion to disqualify failed.[72]

An appeal from an order removing counsel of record for the claimant in a family law case was allowed in Sandhu v. Mangat.[73] The issues in dispute involved parenting of the three young children of the marriage, family property, and both child and spousal support. About two years prior, the solicitor had represented the respondent's brother in a family law dispute that was resolved by agreement. On April 7, 2017, the respondent's then counsel wrote to the solicitor about a possible conflict but indicated that the respondent did not object to her representation of the appellant. On August 21, 2017, respondent's then counsel contacted the solicitor again about a possible conflict arising if she intended to take positions in the case that were inconsistent with positions she took when she represented the respondent's brother. Following an exchange, the respondent continued to express no objection to the solicitor's representation of the appellant. However, in September 2017, the respondent and the respondent's brother wrote to the Law Society of British Columbia about the alleged conflict. The respondent's brother also wrote to the solicitor, stating that her representation of the appellant “would materially and adversely” affect her duty to him and his parents as third parties and would seriously prejudice his interest. The solicitor responded by stating that she did not believe she was in a conflict.[74]

On April 5, 2018, the day before the respondent's discovery, the respondent's new counsel advised the solicitor that she would be making an application to have the solicitor removed as counsel on the basis of a conflict of interest. The respondent's discovery did not proceed.[75]

The basis for the respondent's application before the chambers judge was twofold: (1) the solicitor acted for the respondent's brother in his family action, making her privy to confidential information that was at risk of being used in this action; and (2) the solicitor was taking positions in this action contrary to positions she took in the respondent's brother's action. The chambers judge stated the issue as whether the solicitor should be removed as counsel for the appellant because she had acted for the respondent's brother. She then reviewed the legal principles which have been applied where lawyers act against former clients, quoting extensively from AC&D Insurance Services Ltd. v. Simmons, 2016 CarswellBC 692, 2016 BCSC 452. The principles referred to in AC&D Insurance Services Ltd. v. Simmons are that a lawyer may not act against a former client where two retainers are “sufficiently related” and (i) the lawyer cannot establish that no confidential information was imparted in the first retainer, or (ii) the lawyer is taking an adversarial position against a former client with respect to a matter central to the first retainer. The chambers judge considered that the discretion to disqualify a lawyer may be applied more readily in a family law case. The Chambers judge then considered two areas of overlap between the two actions: the ability of the respondent's mother to look after her grandchildren, and a loan made by the respondent's brother to the parties. She also considered a “third area of potential overlap” to do with the respondent's business for which the respondent's brother and his parents worked from time to time. The Chambers judge did not accept the appellant's submission that the respondent, by counsel's letter of April 7, 2017, had expressly waived any potential conflict. She did not consider counsel's statement that his client did not object to her representing the appellant as an unequivocal waiver. She referred to the correspondence between counsel and the solicitor in late August and early September 2017, in which counsel cautioned the solicitor about advancing inconsistent positions. The Chambers judge was satisfied that the two cases were sufficiently related and that it was reasonably possible that the solicitor, despite her lack of memory of details regarding the earlier case, acquired confidential information in the first matter that “could be relevant” to the current one, and that there was a risk that it could be misused. The Chambers judge also found that the solicitor had and would continue to take positions contrary to those she took for the respondent's brother, perhaps to the detriment of the respondent's brother, and in representing the appellant. The Chambers judge held that confidence in the administration of justice could not be maintained “where lawyers attack their clients or former clients in related matters” and concluded that the risks of disclosing confidential information and the damage to the representation of the legal profession in the administration of justice in taking positions contrary to those she maintained with her former client outweighed the appellant's right to be represented by counsel of her choice.[76]

Justice Fisher observed that in Wallace v. Canadian Pacific Railway, 2013 CarswellSask 432, 2013 SCC 39, the court noted that the law of conflicts is mainly concerned with two types of prejudice: (1) that caused by a lawyer's misuse of confidential information, and (2) that arising where a lawyer's representation is compromised by his or her own interests or the interests of another client or third person. The court also confirmed that the law distinguishes between former and current clients.[77]

Justice Fisher explained that there were two competing values at play. The first was the maintenance of high standards in the legal profession and integrity in the administration of justice. The second was that a litigant should not be deprived of counsel of her choice without good cause. In MacDonald Estate, the Court set out a two-part test aimed to protect against the disclosure and misuse of confidential information by a lawyer against a former client: (1) Did the lawyer receive confidential information attributable to a solicitor and client relationship relevant to the matter at hand? (2) Is there a risk that it will be used to the prejudice of the client? Where these questions are answered in the affirmative, a former client's right to confidentiality takes precedence over a current client's right to counsel of choice.[78]

The fundamental issue is whether the previous retainer is “sufficiently related” to the present retainer. If it is, a court will infer that confidential information was imparted unless the lawyer discharges the burden of satisfying the court that no relevant information was imparted. Where the two retainers are sufficiently related and the lawyer does not satisfy the burden, disqualification will be automatic.[79]

Justice Fisher observed that there may also be a broader objective when considering a lawyer's duties to former clients. In Brookville Carriers Flatbed GP Inc. v. Blackjack Transport Ltd., 2008 CarswellNS 108, 2008 NSCA 22, Justice Cromwell held that even where confidential information is not at risk, the duty of loyalty to a former client may disqualify a lawyer who takes an adversarial position against a former client, undermining the legal work previously done, where it relates to a matter that was central to the previous retainer.[80]

In McKercher, the Supreme Court of Canada confirmed that a lawyer's “main duty” to a former client is to refrain from misusing confidential information, which suggests that there may be some room to consider other duties to former clients that stem from the duty of loyalty. Given this, Justice Fisher was prepared to accept that the duty of loyalty to a former client may in very limited circumstances extend beyond the duty of confidentiality.[81]

Justice Fisher would not accede, however, to the respondent's brother's submission that it makes little sense to draw rigid distinctions between current and former clients. As the court in McKercher explained, the “bright line” rule that applies to avoid conflicts with current clients applies regardless of whether the client matters are related or unrelated. This is, and remains, an important distinction. As Cromwell J.A. acknowledged in Brookville Carriers, the scope of the duty to former clients is very limited absent confidential information being at risk, and it requires a very close relationship between the two retainers. It was important, in his view, that this principle not be applied too broadly. Justice Fisher agreed with those comments.[82]

Justice Fisher explained that this was not a case where the lawyer was acting against a former client. The solicitor in representing the appellant, was not acting against the respondent's brother, but rather against the respondent in a family law case involving different parties and different issues in a different context. Thus, the principles described in the cases referred to above were not readily applicable. The fact that the respondent's brother was to be a witness for the respondent did not change the analysis. It was Justice Fisher's view that the respondent's application before the chambers judge was misguided. It was based on two main concerns: the respondent's brother's interests and the solicitor's taking inconsistent positions from those she took when she represented the respondent's brother. However, the brother's interests were not at stake in this litigation, and the respondent did not establish that his interests would be adversely affected by the solicitor's retainer with the appellant.[83]

The respondent's submissions referred only tangentially to his legal interests and instead focused almost entirely on his brother's interests. This demonstrated that the respondent's interests were not truly engaged and the application should have been brought by the brother as a third party to the proceedings. Instead, the brother was given “standing” to make submissions before both the Chambers judge and the Court of Appeal. In Justice Fisher's view, this unusual circumstance engaged the principle that a third party does not have the same interest and cannot assert the respondent's rights and privileges as a client. In Gichuru v. Purewal, 2017 CarswellBC 3466, 2017 BCCA 281, the Court concluded that a third party's interest in a removal application relates to whether there is a “substantial risk of a compromised trial process”. No such arguments were advanced here.[84]

In any event, Justice Fisher observed that the fact that the brother's interests were paramount in the respondent's application demonstrated the absence of prejudice to the respondent from any knowledge the solicitor may have had of information from the brother, confidential or otherwise, about either the loan or his mother's ability to assist him in caring for his children. In fact, assuming that the solicitor was obligated not to take a position in this litigation contrary to those she took when representing the respondent's brother, any prejudice arising from that would be to the appellant, not the respondent, as it could have caused her to “soft-pedal” her representation of the appellant.[85]

In Justice Fisher's opinion, the Chambers judge erred by failing to recognize the important distinction between the respondent's position and his brother's position. Courts are to take a cautious approach in disqualification applications. The strictness of the test in MacDonald Estate, and the very limited circumstances in which a lawyer's duty to a former client may extend beyond confidentiality, highlight the danger of applying these principles to circumstances beyond their obvious intent. These legal principles may be instructive, but they are not readily applicable where a lawyer is not acting against a former client.[86]

Justice Fisher accepted that there may be situations whereby a lawyer has received confidential information from a former client that may be relevant to the issues in another case involving different parties. However, the applicant in such a case would have to establish the risk of such confidential information being used to his or her prejudice.[87]

The Chambers judge's failure to recognize the distinction affected her assessment of the relationship between the prior retainer with the respondent's brother and the current retainer with the appellant. This was an error in principle, which resulted in findings that did not meet the legal standard of “sufficiently related” and were not supported by the evidence.[88]

Justice Fisher explained that the requirement that the two retainers be sufficiently related cannot be understated. Absent this, the concerns about the misuse of confidential information are not engaged. The same concerns apply in respect of lawyers taking adversarial positions, demonstrated by Brookville Carriers:

[51] … the relationship between the two retainers must be very close so that the lawyer in the new retainer is attacking or undermining the value of the legal work provided to the former client or effectively changing sides in a matter that was central to the previous retainer.
[55] … The concept of relatedness for this purpose is much narrower and has an entirely different focus than the concept as applied in the MacDonald Estate analysis.

The “sufficiently related” requirement is a heightened one for this broader duty of loyalty, as it requires a “very close” relationship between the two retainers and an adversarial position relating to a “central” matter in the previous retainer.[89]
The onus is on the party asserting a conflict to show that the two retainers are sufficiently related, and there must be clear and cogent evidence, not bald assertions, to support such a finding.[90]

The Chambers judge failed to engage in any real analysis of whether the two matters in which the solicitor was retained were related at all, or at least sufficiently related, such that a removal order was warranted. On this issue, the Chambers judge did not explain what issues intersected and overlapped and how this rendered the two retainers “sufficiently related” to engage the principle in MacDonald Estate. Nor did she explain how the relationship between the two retainers was sufficiently close such that the solicitor was “effectively changing sides in a matter that was central to the previous retainer” as described in Brookville Carriers. Simply because there are issues that “intersect and overlap” does not, without more, constitute a sufficient relationship to engage these important principles.[91]

Moreover, the evidence did not support a finding that the two retainers were sufficiently related. Importantly, each retainer involved different parties raising family law issues in a different context. The respondent's concern involved two matters of some commonality—the loan from his brother and the caregiving capacity of the respondent's mother—but when each is assessed in the proper context it was apparent that the issues were not the same in the two retainers. In the brother's case, the issue of the loan was focused on establishing the loan and its value, and it was resolved by an agreement that the brother would be responsible for the parties' debts and entitled to receive payment for loans made, including this loan to the appellant and the respondent. In the appellant's case, the fact of the loan had been admitted and the only issue was whether it was repaid. Whatever the true state of affairs, the brother's legal rights were not engaged in the dispute between the appellant and the respondent. That the brother had commenced a separate action to recover the loan was further evidence of this obvious proposition.[92]

The caregiving issue regarding the capacity of the respondent's mother related to different children of different ages at different periods of time. In the brother's case, he succeeded in obtaining an order for shared parenting of his two children despite complaints by his former wife about his mother's care. To counter these complaints, the solicitor took an affidavit from the mother that attested to her involvement in the care of the brother's children. In the appellant's case, the respondent was also seeking shared parenting, and the appellant was taking issue with the quality of the mother's caregiving. However, the factual issues were different, as they involved three young children at a different period of time. Nothing adduced in evidence or decided in the appellant's case could have any bearing on the brother's legal interests arising from his family law case. The fact that both disputes may involve consideration of the respondent's mother's caregiving abilities did not establish a sufficient relationship between the two retainers.[93]

In the absence of a sufficient relationship between the retainers, there was no need for the Chambers judge to consider the possibility that the solicitor acquired confidential information from the respondent's brother. The Chambers judge went further, however, and applied a broader duty of loyalty not dependent on the risk that confidential information was imparted or misused. Justice Fisher was of the view that the mere fact that a lawyer takes a position that is contrary to a position taken for a former client who is a witness in a current matter does not come close to the circumstances described in Brookville Carriers. In such circumstances, it is difficult to conceive how one could establish a close enough relationship between the two retainers to engage this broader duty of loyalty to a former client.[94]

Moreover, Justice Fisher considered it to be of some importance that the retainer with the respondent's brother did not involve a dispute that went to trial but rather one that was settled between the parties with apparently little input from the solicitor. The chambers judge erred in concluding that the prior retainer was sufficiently related to the retainer with the appellant to engage the principles established in either MacDonald Estate or Brookville Carriers.[95]

The courts retain a discretion not to disqualify a lawyer from acting, regardless of any findings of conflict. To be effective, a waiver must be given with full knowledge of rights and with an unequivocal and conscious intention to abandon those rights. The respondent waived any potential conflict of interest when his then-counsel wrote to the solicitor on April 7, 2017. The letter established that the respondent was well aware that the solicitor had acted for the brother and that his concerns bore no relationship to any prejudice against him. The statement that the respondent “does not object” to the solicitor's representation of the appellant was unequivocal.[96]

The chambers judge considered that the events which followed this letter demonstrated that the waiver was not unequivocal. However, all that occurred subsequently was further clarification of the potential areas of conflict. There was nothing to suggest that these issues changed.[97]

The only other events referred to by the Chambers judge that followed the April 7, 2017 letter were communications between the respondent's brother and the solicitor. However, the brother's objections had no bearing on the respondent's waiver. It was apparent that the Chambers judge failed to appreciate the significance of the fact that the solicitor was not acting against the respondent's brother. There was no evidence that supports the Chambers judge's finding that the respondent's waiver was not unequivocal and there was no evidence that it was ever withdrawn.[98]

Whether or not the respondent's waiver was determinative, his delay in bringing the application to disqualify the solicitor was a factor that the Chambers judge ought to have taken into account in determining whether any relief should have been accorded. The delay clearly caused prejudice to the appellant, as she was required to retain new counsel at a late stage in the litigation and the trial had to be adjourned. The prejudice to the appellant outweighed any prejudice to the respondent or to the respondent's brother.[99]

The only issue of any real to concern to the respondent's brother was the possibility that the solicitor would cross-examine him as a witness at the trial. In this regard, the solicitor must be cognizant of her duty of confidentiality to him as a former client. This is an issue that can arise in many different situations, and one that can be addressed by either counsel or the court, if necessary, in ways much less drastic than disqualifying counsel of record.[100]

In Fereidooni v. Burnham,[101] Justice Ashcroft could not find that “a reasonable member of the public, in possession of the facts would conclude that no unauthorized disclosure of confidential information had occurred or would occur. Gowlings was disqualified from continuing to act for the Defendant. The Plaintiff had been hit as a pedestrian in a crosswalk and sued the Defendant.[102]

The lawyer was an articling student and then an associate at McLeod from July 2013 to February 2016. The Plaintiff was represented by McLeod in the litigation from July 2014 until May 2016. The Associate later moved to another law firm, and then to Gowlings in August, 2016. The Plaintiff alleged that during her time at McLeod, the Associate received privileged and confidential information on the Plaintiff's matter. There was a delay of ten months with the Associate working in the personal injury area of Gowlings and with other lawyers involved in the Defendant's case, before the conflict was acknowledged and screens put in place.[103]

It was not seriously disputed that there existed a previous retainer with McLeod on the file, which was sufficiently related to the current retainer with Gowlings. Accordingly, there existed an inference that confidential information was imparted. Justice Ashcroft concluded that this inference had not been rebutted by the Respondent. Given the presence of two lawyers plus the Associate at the September, 2015 meeting, Justice Ashcroft was prepared to find that confidential information including litigation strategy and settlement prospects, which could be used to the prejudice of the Plaintiff, were likely discussed at the meeting. The Associate had not discharged the “heavy burden” to show that no relevant information was imparted or possessed.[104]

Justice Ashcroft relied on the reasons for judgment delivered in Dow Chemical Canada Inc. v. Nova Chemicals Corp., 2011 CarswellAlta 1394, 2011 ABQB 509, as having provided further direction in the interpretation of MacDonald Estate, by enunciating specific factors which could assist in determining whether there “is a risk that confidential information will be used to the prejudice of the client”:

4. In the era of the mega firm, national or international law firm, imputing the knowledge of one member to all members of the firm is a legal fiction if based solely on the premise that all the lawyers “work together”.

5. Related to the imputed knowledge issue is the proposition that lawyer who work together share information and talk about their cases among and between themselves. A close examination of the size of the firm, the number of locations where the firm is physically located, the residences of the relevant lawyers, are all important considerations.

6. Screening devices to ensure the isolation and compartmentalization of confidential information of a moving lawyer if approved by Law Society Codes of Conduct, are relevant to deciding whether a firm can continue an existing retainer or accept a new retainer.

7. The timing of the erection of screening devices is an important and usually determining factor in deciding whether they are effective in addition to the efficacy of the screening devices themselves, once erected.

8. Notwithstanding all of the foregoing, ultimately the question a court must ask is whether a reasonable member of the public, in possession of all the facts, would conclude that no unauthorized disclosure of confidential information has occurred or will occur.[105]

Justice Ashcroft accepted under the first part of the MacDonald Estate test, that the Associate possessed confidential information. However, the Associate's actual involvement on the file was also relevant to the second part of the test which is concerned with risk of disclosure. At the time of the September 15, 2015 meeting the Associate had been called to the Bar a little over a year. She was no longer an articling student. Her attendance at the meeting was likely required with the intention that she would do some work on the file. However, there was no evidence that she ever did do any work on the file. The Plaintiff stated that he attended many meetings at the offices of the McLeod but also gave evidence that the Associate was in attendance at only one meeting. The Associate had never talked to the Plaintiff on the phone nor did she appear to be copied on emails. No emails or time sheets were provided as evidence supporting that the Associate actually did work on the file. The Associate stated that she had not taken notes at the meeting although that was her practice to do so, further supporting that her involvement was minimal. Justice Ashcroft concluded that the Associate had very little involvement with the file. This weighed against the risk that actual confidential information was transferred or could be transferred to the Plaintiff's prejudice.[106]

Justice Ashcroft recognized that in the age of big mega firms such as Gowlings, one cannot just infer that all confidences are shared. However, the undisputed facts were that the Associate transferred into the same physical offices and the same practice group where the file in question was being worked on and managed. Further, the lawyer who initially recruited the Associate also worked in the same practice group and was one of the lawyers responsible for the file in question. The physical space and interconnected work area supported a risk that confidential information was shared to the prejudice of the Plaintiff.[107]

Justice Ashcroft was satisfied that no information about files was shared at the informal hiring meeting nor would a reasonable person perceive there to be a risk that information was shared. Requiring lawyers to engage in a full conflict screen when simply meeting with a prospective hire is too much of a burden. However, the conflict screens at the time of the actual hire of the Associate in August 2015, were inadequate.
