McLeod was not a large firm and Gowlings knew the Associate worked in the area of personal injury. The Confirmation and Undertaking signed by the Associate did not list all of the files that Gowlings had where McLeod was opposite. It would not have been onerous or impractical for Gowlings to have taken more care to ascertain all the files in which Gowlings acted opposite McLeod in the area of personal injury. This factor did not assist the Respondent in providing “clear and convincing” evidence that rebutted the inference that confidences were shared.[108]

Justice Ashcroft observed that the screens that were implemented after the issue was brought to the attention of Gowlings, including the electronic screens, the physical compartmentalization of the file in a particular area, the restriction that the Associate and lawyers working on the matter do not share an assistant, and that all of the involved lawyers provided affidavits and undertakings that they would not discuss the matter, were adequate to prevent the risk of any future disclosure. The issue that was more difficult to address, however, was the delay in implementing the screens and whether a reasonable member of the public who is in possession of the facts would conclude that no unauthorized disclosure of confidential information had occurred. The delay in the implementation of the screen at over 10 months undermined the efficacy of the screens.[109]

While there would be an expense involved with the transfer of the file, alternative counsel was available. The matter has not yet been set for trial and was not so far in the litigation that the Defendant was prejudiced.[110]

In Gerow v. Dobko,[111] the respondent brought an application to disqualify Fisher and the lawyers at the law firm in which he was a partner from acting for the petitioner in a family law action on the basis that Fisher and other members of the Firm had a conflict of interest arising from their legal dealings with her in the past.[112]

Prior to their marriage, Gerow owned assets, including Humboldt. A pre-nuptial agreement was executed that “stipulated that I would waive all of my rights relating to the division of property…”. The parties separated in 2014 and Gerow has issued a petition for divorce wherein he claimed exemptions based on the pre-nuptial agreement. Dobko disputed the validity of the pre-nuptial agreement and sought an equal division of family property.[113]

Two of the three competing values discussed by Justice Sopinka in MacDonald Estate were at issue here: (1) the concern to maintain the high standards of the legal profession and the integrity of our system of justice, and (2) the countervailing value that a litigant should not be deprived of his or her choice of counsel without good cause. Justice Dufour began by posing one of the two questions MacDonald Estate held must typically be answered: did the lawyer receive confidential information attributable to a solicitor-and-client relationship which is “sufficiently related” to the action at hand? The onus was on Dobko to satisfy the court that there existed a solicitor-client relationship with Fisher and the Firm that is sufficiently related to matters at issue here. If she did, then the onus shifted to the lawyers to establish that no confidential information which could be relevant to this action was imparted to them by Dobko. That, as the Supreme Court noted, is a difficult burden to discharge.[114]

Dobko cited several instances of contact with Fisher and the Firm. In 2002, Gerow retained Fisher to prepare a pre-nuptial agreement, which Fisher did. Dobko did not like it and hired a lawyer to represent her. Justice Dufour observed that the pre-nuptial agreement was clearly related to the action as its interpretation and effect were clearly at issue but she had no solicitor-client relationship with Fisher and the Firm.[115]

Dobko asserted that she had discussions with two lawyers in the Firm in 2014 with respect to three Humboldt employees who were killed in a motor vehicle accident. The legal issue discussed, was whether this would be a Workers' Compensation matter or an SGI claim. There was no evidence to suggest those discussions were in any way related to this family property action. Further, Humboldt Electric was the client—not Dobko. She had never been a director or shareholder of the company.[116]

On Gerow's instructions, the lawyers of the Firm prepared the necessary documents to establish a family trust. Justice Dufour remarked that the fact that the assets in the family trust may ultimately be found to be family property was not relevant to whether Dobko had a solicitor-client relationship with Fisher or lawyers in the Firm. The family trust was relevant to the action as Dobko alleged that family property was transferred into the family trust and one of the issues was whether the property now in the trust was exempt from distribution. Dobko, however, was not the client: Gerow, either in his personal capacity or as trustee, was the client. Further, Dobko gave no instructions and had no discussions with any lawyer at the Firm in respect of the trust. She could not have reposed any confidences in the Firm.[117]

Members of the Firm were involved in the preparation of three sets of Wills for both Gerow and Dobko. In 2003, Scharfstein of the Firm drafted joint Wills for the parties. He received all of his instructions from Gerow and had no discussions at all with Dobko. Justice Dufour concluded that Dobko had a solicitor-client relationship with the Firm even though it was once removed. It was her Will. She was the client. There was no evidence, however, suggesting that her Will was in any way related to issues in the action. Given that she had no discussions with any lawyers of the Firm, she could not have reposed confidential information in it.[118]

In 2010, the Wills were re-drafted by the Firm to change the children's guardians in the event of the parties' mutual passing. Again, she was the Firm's client but, Dobko did not suggest that she had any discussions with anyone in the Firm or indicate how this Will related to any matters at issue in the action.[119]

In 2012, the Wills were re-drafted by the Firm. Dobko indicated that the Wills were drafted by the Firm, based on Gerow's instructions. Dobko had a solicitor-client relationship with the Firm. This time she did have communications with a member of the Firm. In an e-mail, a solicitor with the Firm identified issues relating to mirror clauses in her Will and Gerow's Will: if both parties passed away at the same time, the result could be that five of Glen's family members and his parents could receive double the amount of the money willed to them in each individual Will. Dobko's sole response which was sent two hours later, stated that “obviously this is the problem when we don't both meet with the lawyers to discuss the intention of the wills.” In order to discharge her burden, Dobko was required to provide sufficient evidence, at least in general terms, to enable the Court to find that she probably imparted some nature of confidential information to the solicitor and that which she communicated to her was sufficiently related to this action. Justice Dufour cited the decision of the Ontario Court of Appeal in Chapters Inc. v. Davies, Ward & Beck LLP (2001), 52 O.R. (3d) 566, 2001 CarswellOnt 178:

[29] It is clear from MacDonald Estate that the onus of showing the two retainers to be sufficiently related rests with the client asserting the conflict of interest. It is also clear that it is not enough for that client to rest on a bald assertion that the retainers are sufficiently related. There must be clear and cogent evidence from which the court can reach that conclusion. …

[30] In my opinion this inquiry must be guided by the need to avoid the evil addressed in MacDonald Estate, namely, the possible misuse by the lawyer of information acquired in confidence. Moreover, it is clear that the inquiry must be conducted in a way that preserves that confidence. There may be cases in which a simple description of the two retainers shows them to be so closely connected that the court will infer the possible misuse of confidential information and hence find the retainers to be sufficiently related. More commonly, as in this case, an outline of the nature of the confidential information passed to the lawyer pursuant to the first retainer will be needed. In the end, the client must demonstrate that the possibility of relevant confidential information having been acquired is realistic, not just theoretical. For the court to find that the retainers are sufficiently related, it must conclude that in all the circumstances it is reasonably possible that the lawyer acquired confidential information pursuant to the first retainer that could be relevant to the current matter.[120]

Justice Dufour observed that a lawyer is not conflicted off a file simply because he or she once acted for the opposing party. Other than where there is duty of loyalty to the former client, which was not put in issue in Dobko's application, it was the need to protect the former client from having the confidences she reposed in the lawyer in the course of the previous retainer from prejudicing her in this action. If she did not repose confidences in the lawyer that were sufficiently related to the current action, she could not be prejudiced. As she did not describe any information, much less confidential information, that she reposed in the solicitor during the preparation of the 2012 Will, there was no “evil” to avoid.[121]

Justice Dufour concluded that Dobko failed to discharge her onus to establish that Fisher and the Firm received confidential information attributable to a solicitor-and-client relationship which was “sufficiently related” to this action. Gerow ought not to be deprived of his choice of counsel except for good reason.[122]

In Cy Rheault Construction Ltd. v. Danark Enterprises Limited,[123] the moving party brought a motion for an order for directions with respect to the cross examination of Rheault in respect of his motion to remove Doucet as solicitor for the defendants.[124]

Rheault, the owner of Cy Rheault, retained Doucet, a lawyer, to act for him in matrimonial proceedings. The issues between Rheault and his spouse were strictly financial: spousal support, child support, and equalization of net family property. Throughout the course of the retainer, and in his role as matrimonial counsel, Doucet, became privy to a great deal of information about Rheault's company, Cy Rheault Ltd, including information contained in corporate Minute Books/organizational information, corporate financial statements as well as income tax returns. Rheault terminated Doucet's retainer at a time that the spousal litigation was still ongoing.[125]

Cy Rheault commenced a construction lien action against the moving party relating to a contract between the parties for the demolition of an existing building and the construction of a new building on the lands owned by the moving party. The moving party delivered a Statement of Defence and Counterclaim alleging delays on the part of Cy Rheault as well as deficiencies and non-payment by Cy Rheault of certain sub-trades. The moving party retained Doucet in connection with the construction lien action. Cy Rheault brought a motion to remove Doucet as counsel of record. Doucet served Rheault with a Notice of Cross-Examination, confirming that he would be cross-examining Rheault on his affidavit in support of the removal motion. Rheault objected to Doucet cross-examining him.[126]

Although the removal motion was not before her, Justice Gauthier turned her mind to the law that governs the issue of conflict of interest to inform the decision whether or not Doucet should be permitted to cross-examine his former client and observed that in applying the test, two questions must be answered: (1) did counsel receive confidential information as a result of the solicitor-client relationship, relevant to the matter at hand, and (2) is there a risk that such information will be used to the client's prejudice.[127]

The plaintiff in the construction lien action was the company owned by Rheault. Doucet obtained and continued to have access to personal, private and confidential information about both Rheault and the company against whom Doucet was now acting. It was precisely the financial aspect of the prior divorce proceedings that were of concern to Rheault. Rheault felt that he was being put in a very uncomfortable and unjustifiable position if Doucet, his former counsel, was permitted to cross-examine him about the basis for his perception that Doucet was in a conflict of interest position by virtue of his representation of the moving party in the proceedings against Cy Rheault, being armed with a significant amount of sensitive and confidential financial information.[128]

Justice Gauthier observed that although Doucet's argument that there was no nexus between the information gleaned in the course of the retainer in the matrimonial litigation and the issues in the construction lien action had superficial appeal, in the end, it was not persuasive, nor determinative of the issue, stating:

As well, like the law firm in Canada Trustco Mortgage Co. v. Corkum (1991), 49 C.P.C. (2d) 90 (N.S. T.D.), it is not Doucet's integrity which is in question, but rather the former client's discomfort with the potential use by the former counsel of confidential information, and the potential knowledge of the strengths and weakenesses of Roger Rheault and Cy Rheault company. It is not a stretch to presume that very personal information, together with confidential corporate and financial information was imparted to Doucet in his role as counsel in the matrimonial proceeding. A reasonably informed person would likely assume that the prior relationship between Doucet and Roger Rheault could well give the former a tactical advantage in his litigation strategy against Cy Rheault.[129]

As a result, and out of concern for appearances which might reflect adversely on the integrity of the administration of justice, Justice Gauthier concluded that the moving party's right to be represented by counsel of its choice must yield “to the paramount public interest in preserving the integrity of the system, as well as its appearance”. Accordingly, an Order was made that Doucet was not permitted to conduct or be present for the cross-examination of Rheault on his affidavit. Doucet was not to assist whichever counsel did conduct the cross-examination.[130]

In W.C. Thornton v. Zamirski et al.,[131] it was alleged that Zamirski, on behalf of Nova, contacted Thornton with regard to investment opportunities in litigation financing. It was alleged that Thornton and Nova entered into a series of Investment Loan Contracts. The purpose of the agreements was to fund personal injury claims across the country. Thornton asserted that it paid money to Nova and was promised certain returns on those investments.[132]

The Defendants moved for an Order removing Leitch as counsel for Thornton as a result of an alleged conflict of interest with the Defendants. The Defendants asserted that Leitch was retained by Zderic, the wife of Zamirsk and a director of Nova, in or around June 2015, to incorporate a golf club. The purchase of that club was later funded by Nova. Allegedly, Leitch, through that retainer, acquired confidential information about Nova, and that information might be used against the Defendants in the current litigation. The Defendants' Motion was supported by a very brief Affidavit sworn by Zamirski. It included a bald assertion that Zamirski believed that Leitch, in the current litigation and specifically in the context of Thornton's Motion for summary judgment, had access to confidential information regarding Nova by virtue of the prior retainer concerning the golf club. The Defendants' Motion was supported further by an Affidavit sworn by a legal assistant in the law firm representing the Defendants. That Affidavit, as far as it dealt with the alleged conflict of interest issue, was entirely hearsay. It relied exclusively on information supposedly provided by Zamirski. Ironically, much of that information was not contained in Zamirski's own Affidavit. In any event, the legal assistant's Affidavit stated that Leitch acquired information through the prior retainer about Nova's finances, corporate structure and business activities. The legal assistant's Affidavit pointed to Thornton's Factum in support of its Motion for summary judgment, specifically, Thornton's submission that Zamirski should be held personally liable because the circumstances suggested that Nova may be involved in fraudulent activity and/or because Zamirski may not have had the legal capacity to bind Nova vis a vis the contracts. The implication was that the submission by Thornton was based on confidential information acquired by Leitch through the prior retainer. The legal assistant's Affidavit also pointed to another portion of Thornton's Factum in support of its Motion for summary judgment, specifically, Thornton's submission that the contracts in question may not have been drafted by a lawyer. Again, the implication was that the submission by Thornton was based on confidential information acquired by Leitch through the prior retainer.[133]

Justice Conlan observed that the legal assistant's Affidavit totally ignored the fact that the Factum filed by Thornton on its Motion for summary judgment was not evidence and queried: “So what does it matter if it refers to things that Leitch allegedly obtained in confidence through the prior retainer?”[134]

Further, Justice Conlan accepted that Leitch's prior retainer, even if it was with Zderic, had nothing to do whatsoever with Nova or Zamirski. As such, not only did Leitch not acquire any confidential information about Nova, he had no opportunity to do so. There was no conflict of interest. There was no appearance of any conflict of interest. The two retainers \were not related in any material way. There was no heightened risk, or any risk, of prejudice.[135]

In Scotia Mortgage Corp. v. Furlong,[136] Furlong argued that the law firm representing SMC was in a conflict of interest in bringing power of sale proceedings against him. As a consequence, he sought an Order that SMC was not entitled to recover from him the legal fees incurred by SMC in pursuing that power of sale.[137]

In April 2011, the law firm OB had acted on behalf of Furlong in the purchase of a residential property. SMC provided mortgage financing and OB acted on behalf of both Furlong, as mortgagor, and SMC, as mortgagee. In January 2014 OB merged with the law firm of MC. In March 2016, SMC retained MC as a result of an alleged default under the mortgage by Furlong. The law firm thereafter took an adversarial role on behalf of SMC against its former client. The firm sent a demand letter to Furlong, enclosing a Notice of Mortgage and Sale. It wrote Furlong demanding that he vacate the property immediately, informed him of SMC's intention to proceed with publication of a Notice of Sale by Tender, and provided him with an opportunity to remedy the alleged default. It served him with a Notice to Vacate. Finally, as a result of his refusal to vacate, the law firm issued an Originating Application on behalf of SMC against Furlong, seeking an Order for vacant possession of his property.[138]

The law firm also represented Furlong's former employer, the City of St. John's, in defense of an action commenced by Furlong arising from the termination of his employment by the City. Furlong argued that this retention by the City exacerbated the breach of fiduciary duty owed by the law firm to him as its former client. He submitted that in acting as counsel for both the City and SMC, the law firm could be privy to his confidential information, such as his financial status, and there is a perception, at least, that this information could be employed by the City to his detriment in the wrongful dismissal suit. Furlong conceded that this conflict would no longer exist if the law firm ceased to act as counsel for SMC on the power of sale proceedings.[139]

Under the test in MacDonald it was incumbent on Furlong to establish (i) the existence of a previous relationship, and (ii) that the relationship was “sufficiently related” to the retainer from which the removal of the law firm was sought. If these two elements were proved, the onus shifts to the law firm to satisfy the court that no confidential information was imparted which could be relevant. The presence of relevant confidential information is such as to render the lawyer's disqualification automatic.[140]

The parties agreed that the law firm was the continuation of OB and therefore there was a previous relationship in April 2011 between the firm and Furlong. Counsel for SMC conceded that should Furlong establish that the previous relationship was sufficiently related to the power of sale retainer, there was no evidence before the court to rebut the inference that relevant confidential information was imparted. Therefore, in the absence of such evidence, the test in MacDonald is satisfied if the two retainers were “sufficiently related”.[141]

It was common ground that the two retainers were not the same, but the Court inquired as to whether they were related. In Montreal Trust Co. of Canada v. Basinview Village Ltd. (1995), 142 N.S.R. (2d) 337, 126 D.L.R. (4th) 61 (N.S. C.A.), the bank provided refinancing for two of Bainsview's Properties. At the time, both the bank and Bainsview, as well as its principal, were all represented by the same law firm. When the bank commenced foreclosure proceedings, that firm defended Bainsview and its principal, and in so doing, challenged the validity of the mortgages. The Nova Scotia Court of Appeal concluded that the firm was in conflict. Counsel for SMC submitted that notwithstanding the connection between the two retainers in this instance, they were not “related” in the sense contemplated in Brookville. The enforcement by SMC of its rights under the mortgage could not be viewed as an attack upon, or as undermining the law firm's work on the first retainer. This position was predicated on the fact that in his Response to SMC's application for vacant possession Furlong had not challenged this advice, or the validity of the mortgage per se. The corollary to this argument was that were Furlong to take issue with the legal advice provided to him at the time of signing the mortgage, or challenge the validity of the mortgage, the facts would fall closer to that in Montreal Trust, and a conflict would clearly exist. The judge agreed that in such circumstances the conflict is more obvious, for there is the prospect of the law firm which advised on the mortgage challenging or defending its own advice. However, at the time of accepting its retainer from SMC, the law firm would have no way of knowing what would be Furlong's response to the power of sale proceedings. The problem with the approach advocated by SMC was twofold; first, the outcome was unpredictable and second, it ignores the fiduciary duty owed by the firm to its former client.[142]
The court in Brookville provided the following overview of the legal principles in play when determining if retainers are “related”:

51. Under the principle relevant here, that concerning acting against a former client in a related matter, the focus is different. As the cases and commentators show, the scope of this duty is very limited absent confidential information being at risk. This broader continuing duty of loyalty to former clients is based on the need to protect and to promote public confidence in the legal profession and the administration of justice. What is of concern is the spectre of a lawyer attacking or undermining in a subsequent retainer the legal work which the lawyer did for the former client or of a lawyer effectively changing sides by taking an adversarial position against a former client with respect to a matter that was central to the previous retainer. Basinview Village Ltd. is an example of the former: the new retainer involved the lawyer attacking or attempting to undermine the very legal services provided to the former client. Harris and Chiefs of Ontario are examples of the latter: the new retainer involved attacks on the honesty and integrity of the former client in relation to exactly the same sort of matters as the lawyer acted to defend in the previous retainer. In either type of case, the relationship between the two retainers must be very close so that the lawyer in the new retainer is attacking or undermining the value of the legal work provided to the former client or effectively changing sides in a matter that was central to the previous retainer. [emphasis added][143]

At the time of his purchase in 2011, Furlong was provided with legal advice on his rights and obligations under the mortgage with SMC. This advice would have been central to the firm's retainer at the time. In the second retainer, the firm was called upon to enforce those very same obligations against Furlong in pursuit of SMC's rights under the mortgage. Simply put, the firm was now suing Furlong on the very document for which it advised him in 2011. Furlong's rights and obligations under the mortgage were now the core of the law firm's representation of SMC, in a manner that was adverse to Furlong. Furlong was entitled to assume in 2011 that the law firm then advising him would not in a few years be suing him on the very document for which their advice was given. The judge was satisfied that the mortgage was central to both retainers. The two retainers were thus related. As a result, the law firm was in conflict in acting on behalf of SMC in the power of sale proceedings against its former client.[144]

Having concluded that the law firm was in conflict of interest, the question remained whether SMC was nevertheless entitled to claim against Furlong the legal fees it incurred during the period of the conflict. A conflict of interest does not create an “absolute bar” to the payment of solicitors' fees and such a determination depends on the facts in each case. The judge concluded that it could not be said that Furlong had in any way “benefited” from the work conducted by the law firm. To the contrary, all actions to date, undertaken while that firm was in a conflict of interest, had been to his detriment. These actions culminated in an application for vacant possession of his property. The argument that the fees would have been incurred by some firm, regardless, might be made in a large number of cases where a conflict of interest is found to exist after the conflict has been identified. To permit the recovery of fees in such circumstances, particularly where the fees have been incurred to the detriment of the client would, be to erode in a very real way the transparency and fairness integral to legal representation in the adversarial system. To award costs in such a circumstance would undermine the duty of loyalty owed to Furlong. The judge concluded that SMC was not entitled to recover the legal fees incurred by the law firm in its pursuit of the power of sale against Furlong.[145]

A motion brought by the defendants in Sim & McBurney v. Aird & McBurney LP[146] to disqualify counsel for the plaintiff from representing the plaintiff further in the proceeding was granted and an order was made that the solicitor be removed as solicitor for the plaintiff in the action.[147]

The action arose from the decision of four dissident and former partners of the plaintiff to change firms. Between late July and September 2015, the four partners held discussions with the law firm now representing the plaintiff about the possibility of moving their practice to that firm. An introductory meeting was held in late July between some members of the dissident group and a partner of the law firm. A non-disclosure agreement was sent by the dissident partner group to the law firm on August 2, 2015 and signed back by the law firm. On August 14, 2015 a USB drive containing client lists of the four dissident partners as well as their billings, hourly rates and compensation was sent to the law firm. The information received was reviewed by four members of the law firm's management and two senior patent agents from the law firm's intellectual property group and two employees who conducted conflicts checks on the client lists. A follow-up meeting was held in mid-September, 2015 to discuss the information provided and answer questions arising. The law firm admitted to having had discussions of the dissidents' difficulties at the plaintiff firm, clients who might follow them if they moved, other partners, staff and associates who might choose to leave and who among them might be desirable acquisitions, compensation and billing history, etc. All of these are indeed “typical” and expected subjects of conversation in such negotiations. Those discussions ultimately did not bear fruit. The defendants objected to the law firm representing the plaintiff on the grounds that the law firm possessed confidential information that could be used to their detriment in this proceeding and that partners of the firm were likely material witnesses on matters central to the claim whose testimony would be needed at trial.[148]

The defendants raised the potential conflict issues promptly after receiving the statement of claim and realizing that complaints going beyond the use of the firm name were included in the claim. This motion was brought shortly thereafter. There were three distinct categories of claims pleaded in the statement of claim. Firstly, the plaintiff made a common-law passing off claim as well as advancing statutory causes of action under the Trade-marks Act in connection with the use of the name “Aird & McBurney” by the defendants resulting in alleged confusion with the services of the plaintiff and alleged infringement of their trade-mark. There was no suggestion that there were any discussions of this issue with the law firm. Secondly, the plaintiff has alleged that McBurney was bound to it in contract following his retirement and that he breached his agreement by entering into a consulting arrangement with the defendant Aird & McBurney and co-operating with the latter in soliciting former clients of the plaintiff. The defendants were alleged to have induced breach of his contract. The evidence as to whether McBurney was discussed with the law firm was in dispute. It was, at all events, not a main or central point of the discussions. Finally, the claim sought damages against Aird & Berlis “for inducement and/or provision of knowing assistance with respect to breaches of fiduciary duty, trust, good faith and loyalty owed to the plaintiff by three of the four dissidents (the three patent agents in the group). It was primarily in respect of this third category of claim that the alleged conflict arose.[149]

The inherent jurisdiction of the court to disqualify counsel from acting in the face of a conflict of interest is not restricted to conflicts arising from a solicitor-client relationship or one “near” to that. While the protection of the sanctity of the solicitor-client relationship is clearly a core value of the judicial system, it is not the only value. A conflict can arise where a solicitor has a recognized obligation of confidentiality that conflicts with his or her obligation to advance the interests of a client in litigation. Where a lawyer receives information in circumstances giving rise to a reasonable expectation of privacy or confidentiality, that communication may be protected in a fashion similar to information disclosed in the context of the solicitor-client relationship. There are few moments in the life of a lawyer where he or she is more vulnerable than when contemplating moving law firms. The mere whisper of the fact that a lawyer is looking at another firm could be enough to jeopardize his or her career. The delicate job of contacting, meeting and negotiating between candidate firm and candidate lawyer is deservedly considered by both sides to such discussions as a matter requiring the utmost confidentiality. The three dissident partners who were patent agents instead of lawyers were in no less precarious a position after their years of close association with a law firm. All four dissident partners had a reasonable expectation of confidentiality attending their meetings and negotiations with the law firm that pre-dated the delivery of an NDA and survived the termination of their negotiations. Each had a reasonable right to expect that the law firm would keep the information conveyed, including the fact of their meetings, confidential.[150]

The plaintiff appeared to treat the matter of confidentiality as being restricted to the contents of the USB drive received by the law firm in August 2015. However, the motions judge concluded that the entire discussion—including the fact of the discussion—was confidential. The reasonable expectation of confidentiality did not cease when the four dissident partners elected to make arrangements with another law firm. The dissident partners had a reasonable expectation that the law firm would not make public, for example, their compensation or billings history over the past years simply because the negotiations failed to result in an agreement. Furthermore, the NDA by its terms extended to all confidential information imparted in the process and was not limited to documents. There was no question that the law firm came into possession of information obtained from the dissident partners that was imparted in circumstances giving rise to a reasonable expectation of confidentiality.[151]

The plaintiff chose to target its claims against the new firms with whom the dissidents had become associated and had not joined the dissident partners personally. In the motion judge's view, that was a distinction without a difference. There could be no question that the law firm had no license to use information it received from the four dissident partners against their interests and this litigation directly affected both the reputation and pocket books of the dissident partners in their relationship with the defendant firms.[152]

The answer to the question of whether the confidential information held by the law firm placed it in conflict with its duties to the plaintiff requires a consideration of (i) whether the information received by the law firm was relevant to the matter at hand; and (ii) whether there was a risk that it will be used to the prejudice of the party to whom the duty is owed. There was no question that, based upon the statement of claim, the information relating to the now disclosed fact of negotiations with the dissident partners and their substance was both relevant and material to the breach of fiduciary duty and related claims advanced by the plaintiff in the statement of claim. The statement of claim took specific issue with the solicitation of professional and non-professional staff from the plaintiff and the disclosure of client lists—these precise matters were the object of discussions and negotiations with the law firm. The evidence satisfied the “substantial relationship” test. Every aspect of the negotiations with the law firm would be relevant and potentially material to the plaintiff in framing and prosecuting its claim and preparing its discovery plan. There remained considerable risk that the information may be used to the prejudice of the defendants. The parties who received the information swore affidavits that they had not discussed the confidential information with the litigation team at the law firm. That was not entirely accurate at least to the extent that the fact and nature of the discussions were revealed to the litigation team. No formal ethical wall was put in place when the conflict was discovered and none was in place now.[153]

The plaintiff could not answer this charge by stating that simply the documents will be produced on discovery in any event. The contents of negotiations, the expectations of the parties communicated, their business plans and strategies, their grievances with the plaintiff firm and discussions of personnel who might follow them—all of these are matters that would be relevant and material to the claim advanced by the plaintiff in this case. The risk extended far beyond mere documents. A plaintiff fore-armed with confidential information can tailor a claim or a discovery plan around that information. Accordingly, the moving party defendants demonstrated the existence of a conflict between the law firm's obligations to maintain confidentiality of the information disclosed by the four dissidents and its obligations towards its own client. The information was received by the law firm in circumstances where there existed a reasonable expectation of confidentiality that was understood and appreciated by the law firm. The information received was both material and relevant to the litigation the law firm had undertaken on behalf of the plaintiff and there remained a risk of the misuse of that information that was neither fanciful nor slight.[154]
The correct approach in the motion judge's view was the one adopted in Greenbriar Holding Inc. v. Canadian Hydrogen Energy Co., 2006 CarswellOnt 4889, [2006] O.J. No. 3242 (Ont. S.C.J.), at para. 10:

Generally, in these situations, the court must balance the right of a litigant to retain the lawyer he or she wishes against the right of a party adverse in interest to be secure in the knowledge that there will be no misuse of confidential information obtained by opposing counsel to the adverse party's detriment. The court must consider these issues from the point of view of the reasonable person, and have regard to both the appearance of conflict, not just actual conflict, as well as the risk of prejudice, not just actual prejudice.

If a remedy short of removing the solicitor will cure the problem, it should be considered. Factors include a consideration of how the information came into the possession of the solicitor, what steps were taken upon recognition of the potential conflict, the stage of litigation, the potential effectiveness of a firewall or other precautionary steps to avoid the mischief.[155]

The evidence was a very long way from establishing that a robust and thorough ethical wall has been put in place that would pass scrutiny. The law firm did not react to its discovery of the possible conflict by immediately applying a comprehensive and effective ethical wall. Offering to do so now was rather late in the day. The lack of a swift and monitored ethical wall meant that it was impossible to verify the degree to which the confidential information had effectively been restricted to a limited group. The lack of an immediate and effective prophylactic response to the conflict situation weighed against permitting the law firm to remain in place. The plaintiff had a right to counsel of its choice, but it did not have the right to select counsel with an “edge” unfairly gained. The fact that the law firm approached the whole issue of confidentiality from the limited perspective of the relatively limited number of documents exchanged raised legitimate apprehensions that other forms of confidential information including face-to-face negotiations and dialogue had not been treated with the same level of concern. The early stage of this litigation was a factor that supported acting now to cure the conflict decisively when the investment of the plaintiff in its counsel of choice both in terms of fees expended and experience and “file knowledge” acquired was at its lowest. It was not reasonable to ask the defendants to accept that their adversary's counsel should continue in its role subject only to an ethical wall that might now be put in place this long after the fact. The appropriate remedy to deal with the conflict of interest relating to the law firm's role in this matter was to remove them as solicitor of record for the plaintiff.[156]

The moving parties in 2235512 Ontario Inc. v. 2235541 Ontario Inc.[157] sought orders removing the solicitors of record for the Applicants and prohibiting the solicitors from acting as counsel for the Applicants or their shareholders in any dispute involving UniversalCare and its shareholders and principals. The motion arose from an allegation that the Applicants' lawyers were in a conflict of interest because, as former counsel for one of the corporate Respondents, they could not now act on behalf of one of the shareholders of the former client, against both the former client and the remaining shareholder.[158]

In the application, the Applicants sought orders allowing the Applicants to purchase various entities that were equally owned by the Applicants and certain of the Respondents, on the basis that the entities were deadlocked.[159]

Courts have an inherent jurisdiction to remove a lawyer or law firm from the record on the basis of a conflict of interest. Lawyers owe their clients a fiduciary duty to avoid conflicts of interest. A solicitor cannot give his exclusive, undivided attention to the interests of his client if he is torn between his client's interests and his own or his client's interests and those of another client to whom he owes the same duty of loyalty, dedication, and good faith. Courts have found that internal corporate shareholder disputes create “inherent conflicts of interest that effectively restrict a lawyer's ability to extend joint representation”. Courts should be on guard to ensure conflict motions are not brought for a tactical advantage. When a corporation retains a solicitor, he or she is not the solicitor for the individual shareholders in the absence of a further retainer.[160]

The primary question was about the solicitor's relationship with UniversalCare, one of the parties against whom the solicitor was acting in this proceeding. The solicitor was counsel of record for both Applicants, one of them being 512, a fifty percent shareholder in UniversalCare. The solicitor was acting against UniversalCare, its former client, and 541. 541 was the other of UniversalCare's two shareholders. The solicitor had acted in previous matters on behalf of UniversalCare. The solicitor was not acting for UniversalCare on an ongoing basis. The issue was the nature of MT's prior retainer by UniversalCare. While the solicitor had no ongoing solicitor/client relationship with UniversalCare, the solicitor did previously have such a relationship and that such touched on corporate issues unrelated to these proceedings but included services in relation to the AllianceCare project.[161]

This proceeding had been commenced by way of Notice of Application. There are no rules of pleading per se in respect of motions. The rules do require that the moving party deliver a motion record. Of particular note was the fact no reference was made to the AllianceCare project as formulating a basis for the allegation of conflict of interest. Before cross-examinations were conducted and before argument was entertained, the moving parties had presented evidence relating to the AllianceCare issue. The Applicants had not been surprised by the AllianceCare issue. The evidence in relation to AllianceCare was before the court and related by the moving parties to the conflict issue prior to cross-examination. It was thus relevant, even though it was not specifically referenced in the Notice of Motion. The requirement that a moving party include Grounds for the motion is designed to promote procedural fairness by alerting a responding party to the material issues in play, supplemented by a broad description of the main allegations of fact. Here the notice of motion referenced the allegation of conflict of interest. A reply affidavit referenced the AllianceCare project prior to cross-examinations and related it to the conflict issue. There was no basis to conclude that the Applicants had been prejudiced in these circumstances. Even if AllianceCare could be added as a party, such is not a necessary pre-condition to rendering questions in relation to AllianceCare relevant. The relevance of questions at cross-examination is determined by defined issues, not by who is or is not a party. It was apparent from the evidence that AllianceCare represented an important component of the dispute between the parties. It was not proper for the Applicants to refuse to answer the questions put to them regarding AllianceCare and it was open to the motion judge to draw an adverse inference to the effect that answers to the questions refused would have been unhelpful to the Applicants' position on the motion. The questions refused were directed at determining the nature of the work performed and information received by the solicitor in relation to the AllianceCare project. Answers would have shed light on whether the solicitor received confidential information attributable to a solicitor/client relationship relevant to a matter at hand. The refusals led the motion judge to draw an inference that had the answers been provided such would likely have supported the moving parties' position on this issue that confidential information had been obtained. According to McKercher, there is a rebuttable presumption that a lawyer possesses confidential information that raises the risk of prejudice if a new retainer is “sufficiently related” to the matters on which he or she worked for the former client. The rebuttable presumption in McKercher is supplemented by the adverse inferences drawn from the Applicants refusal to answer questions regarding the AllianceCare project. The concern was that the past representation by the solicitor of UniversalCare provided access to confidential information that was sufficiently related to the subject matter of the current dispute. The motion judge concluded that the solicitor did receive confidential information attributable to a solicitor/client relationship relevant to the matter at hand. The motion judge also concluded that there was a risk that the confidential information would be used to the prejudice of the client, given that the rebuttable presumption of risk had not been rebutted in light of the failure to answer relevant questions.[162]

The motion judge appreciated that an order removing counsel imposed a hardship upon the Applicants but on balance this was lesser than the harm occasioned by permitting counsel to continue in the circumstances.[163]

The motion judge concluded that the relief sought by the moving parties in the form of a prohibition against the solicitor acting as counsel for the Applicants on their shareholders in any dispute involving UniversalCare and its shareholders and principals was overbroad. Should the issue arise in future disputes between the parties it could and should be addressed within the context of the proceeding in which the issue arises.[164]

In Frontier Property Investments Ltd. v. Wellworth Homes Ltd.,[165] allegations of conflict of interest and breach of fiduciary duty did not raise a bona fide triable issue in the foreclosure proceeding. A loan transaction was made pursuant to which Frontier agreed to loan funds to Wellworth Homes to enable Wellworth Homes to purchase two lots for the purpose of constructing and selling two single family homes. The loan was in the form of a demand loan and was secured by a mortgage granted by Wellworth Homes to Frontier over the subject property. While Wellworth Homes constructed the planned homes, they had been unable to sell them and, as a result, defaulted on the loan from Frontier. This caused Frontier to make a demand under the loan and to commence foreclosure proceedings. A Master granted an order nisi. At the hearing before the Master, Wellworth Homes argued that the matter should not be decided summarily but should be referred to the trial list. The primary ground advanced in support of this position related to one of the principals of Frontier, a lawyer with a firm that had acted as the long-time solicitors for Wellworth Homes and Wellworth Group. Wellworth Homes alleged that the lawyer who acted for Frontier on the loan transaction was in a conflict of interest position and had misused confidential information when negotiating and concluding the loan agreement.[166]
The lawyer had advised that he would be signing the relevant loan documents as a representative of Frontier so Wellworth Homes would need a different lawyer to act for it.[167]

There had been discussions, primarily between a principal of Wellworth Homes, and the lawyer about the status of the properties and the loan. As part of these discussions, in an email to the principal of Wellworth Homes, the lawyer encouraged the principal to continue to look for long-term financing and he suggested that whether Wellworth Homes found such financing or Frontier continued its financing arrangement, “I believe you will need to bring in Anchor Mechanical and yourselves personally if you are to be able to provide sufficient security to move forward.” The principal of Wellworth Homes alleged that the lawyer, and Frontier, would only have known about Anchor, and its connection to Wellworth Homes, by virtue of the law firm's solicitor-client relationship with the various Wellworth entities. The principal of Wellworth Homes was of the view that the request for a guarantee from Anchor was of concern as it was apparent to him that Frontier had access to confidential information about Wellworth Homes' corporate structures and related entities and that Frontier was willing to make use of that confidential information to its benefit, and to the detriment of Wellworth Homes. The principal of Wellworth Homes e-mailed the lawyer advising him of the concern about a conflict of interest and the misuse of confidential information.[168]

The court observed that Wellworth Homes made extensive submissions concerning a solicitor's duties of loyalty and fidelity and the importance of protecting confidential client information, as well as the wide range of remedies available for a breach of fiduciary duty. The trial judge had no issue with these points. However, in the specific circumstances, the court was unable to find that Wellworth Homes had raised a bona fide triable issue about the validity of the loan transaction and related security that would warrant referring this matter to the trial list. Wellworth Homes, its principals, and the related Wellworth entities, were sophisticated business actors who had engaged in numerous similar transactions in the past. Wellworth Homes was fully aware of the lawyer's involvement with Frontier and his employment by the law firm. Wellworth Homes was referred to, and retained, separate counsel to act for it on the loan transaction. Wellworth Homes had independent legal advice available to it and that solicitor negotiated some of the terms of the loan agreement with the lawyer. Wellworth Homes provided no specifics as to the confidential information allegedly misused or how the terms of the transaction would have been different but for the alleged breaches.[169]

In Hogarth v. Hogarth,[170] the moving parties Connie and Anthony jointly brought a motion to remove the solicitor and the law firm as lawyer for the respondent Tim. Connie and Tim were currently parties in the matrimonial litigation. Antony was a party in matrimonial litigation brought in relation to his marriage. Connie and Antony were currently in a “committed relationship”, which was not defined by either of them, except that they both acknowledged they were not cohabiting.[171]

In September 2015, Antony's counsel, Snelius advised Nella that Snelius was ill. Snelius advised Antony to meet with several counsel, including the solicitor, to decide who Antony wanted to retain as Antony's counsel in the Nella Litigation. On September 27, 2015, Antony met with the solicitor and his associate for that purpose. At the September 27, 2015 meeting, Antony alleged that he advised the solicitor and his associate that Antony was dating Connie. Antony chose not to retain the solicitor and advised the solicitor of his decision three days after the Meeting.[172]

Tim filed an answer in which he alleged that he discovered text messages between Antony and Connie that led him to conclude they were having an affair; and after Tim and Connie separated, Connie spent extravagant sums on trips with her “boyfriend” who was Antony.[173]

The moving parties submitted that the solicitor must be removed as Tim's lawyer since the solicitor breached his duty of confidence and used confidential information from Antony relevant to the Hogarth Litigation.[174]

Justice Glustein observed that confidential information is information one would not ordinarily reveal to an opposing lawyer. It includes such matters as personal expenses, assets, and liabilities, as well as information about the “personal habits, faults and foibles of the ‘client’, knowledge of which might be valuable to the lawyer in the adversarial world of litigation”. If a former client can establish that there existed a previous relationship which is sufficiently related to the retainer from which it is sought to remove the solicitor, the court should infer that confidential information was imparted which could be relevant “unless the solicitor satisfies the court that no information was imparted which could be relevant”. That burden must be discharged without revealing the specifics of the privileged communication.[175]

The former client bears the onus of showing that the previous retainer is sufficiently related to the current retainer. The former client must adduce “clear and cogent” evidence, not mere assertions that the two retainers are sufficiently related. The former client must show that the possibility of relevant confidential information having been acquired is realistic, not just theoretical.[176]

In order to consider whether the Nella Litigation and Hogarth Litigation were sufficiently related, the moving parties relied on (i) the fact that they were both involved in ongoing matrimonial litigation, (ii) the documents and e-mails delivered to the solicitor for review in relation to the Meeting as well as the solicitor's telephone conversation and e-mails with Snelius prior to the Meeting, (iii) an alleged conversation during the Meeting in which Antony told the solicitor[177] that Antony was dating Connie, and (iv) the allegations in the Answer relating to Antony.[178]

In his affidavit, Antony provided no description of the Nella Litigation, except to state that “I am currently involved in family law litigation with my wife”. The moving parties did not file any pleadings from the Nella Litigation. Consequently, Justice Glustein could not find that the Nella and Hogarth Litigations were sufficiently related based on the pleadings. Rather, Antony relied on an overview of the Nella Litigation set out in an e-mail letter from Snelius to the solicitor, provided prior to the Meeting.[179]

The solicitor was never retained as Antony's lawyer in the Nella Litigation. The solicitor and his associate met with Antony for a brief meeting. The mere existence of two independent matrimonial litigations in the circumstances where Antony and Connie happen to be dating, along with the delivery of materials related to the Nella Litigation prior to the Meeting did not satisfy the test that the Nella and Hogarth Litigations were sufficiently related.[180]

Antony alleged that at the Meeting, he told the solicitor and his associate that Antony and Connie were dating. Justice Glustein concluded that (i) the conversation did not occur, and (ii) even if it did, there was no relevant confidential information disclosed. The associate's lengthy contemporaneous notes of the discussions at the Meeting made no reference at all to Connie. The notes referred to the fact that Antony's wife was dating someone else, and to numerous other issues relevant to the Nella Litigation. There was no basis to conclude that the associate would not have recorded in her notes that Antony was dating Connie.[181]

The fact that Antony and Connie were dating was not confidential. They were in a “committed relationship” and there was no evidence that they kept the relationship secret. The fact that Antony and Connie were dating would not be relevant to the Hogarth Litigation. While the issue of whether Connie was spending extravagant sums on travel with Antony after separation was raised in the Answer, there was no evidence from Antony that he discussed that issue at the Meeting.[182]

The moving parties relied on the allegations in the Answer in which Tim pleaded: (a) “In 2005, Tim discovered a series of text messages between Connie and her current boyfriend, Antony Nella, the content of which led Tim to conclude that she was then having an affair. Tim was devastated. Connie denied the affair, and Tim took her at her word”; and (b) “Rather than curb her spending [after the separation], Connie embarked on an unprecedented spending spree. Expenditures included extravagant travel, such as Connie's taking her boyfriend to luxurious resorts in Thailand and Jamaica”.[183]

Justice Glustein concluded that these allegations did not support the moving parties' submission that the solicitor obtained relevant confidential information from Antony. In particular, the uncontested evidence of Tim was that he was the source of the information underlying the allegations. The solicitor's unchallenged evidence was that Antony was not the source of the information that gave rise to the allegations. Further, Antony filed no evidence to challenge the solicitor's and Tim's clear statement that Antony had not provided the information. Consequently, there was no basis to find that Antony provided any confidential information which formed the basis for the allegations in the Answer.[184]

The moving parties had not established that the Nella Litigation and Hogarth Litigation were sufficiently related such as to result in a presumption that Antony provided confidential information to the solicitor relevant to the Hogarth Litigation. The evidence about the Meeting and the documents and emails provided in relation to the Meeting did not meet the requirement of “clear and cogent” evidence necessary to remove Tim's counsel of choice. A fair minded and reasonably informed member of the public would not conclude that the proper administration of justice compelled the solicitor's removal.[185]

Further, Antony had not established that the solicitor actually possessed relevant confidential information from him arising from the Meeting. Even if Antony's evidence was accepted that he advised the solicitor that Antony was dating Connie, there was no evidence to support that this information was confidential or relevant.[186]

The Federal Court's order in Valeant Canada LP v. Canada (Minister of Health)[187] resulted from a motion brought by Valeant within an application for prohibition it brought under the Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations for disqualification of the respondent's in-house lawyer from any further involvement in the application before the court on the ground that he could be presumed to have Valeant's confidential information. That application was triggered by the respondent serving a notice of allegation on Valeant. The Federal Court granted Valeant's motion to disqualify the solicitor but declined to declare the notice of allegation invalid and to grant relief related thereto. It held that it lacked the jurisdiction to do so.[188]

Valeant learned that the law firm purported to represent the respondent and that it was involved in preparing the notice of allegation. The law firm was the law firm of its predecessor for many years until 2008. In the period leading up to 2008, the law firm had represented the predecessor in five proceedings in the Federal Court relating the same medicinal ingredient that was the subject-matter of the notice of allegation. Valeant registered its objection with the law firm. Soon after receiving the objection, the law firm resigned as Cobalt's counsel. The law firm's resignation as counsel and undertaking not to act or assist further did not satisfy Valeant. In Valeant's view, two problems remained. First, Cobalt employed a solicitor as in-house counsel who had during the last two years that the law firm represented Valeant's predecessor in its patent litigation was employed by the law firm as a student-at-law and, later, as a lawyer. Second, Cobalt's notice of allegation was in Valeant's view a direct product of the law firm's improper use of confidential information gathered from its earlier retainers with Valeant's predecessor. Accordingly, Valeant brought a motion for an order disqualifying the solicitor, declaring the notice of allegation invalid, and other relief related to the declaration.[189]

The Federal Court of Appeal agreed that the motions judge did not apply the Martin test exactly as set out by the Supreme Court. Nevertheless, the motions judge had reached the correct result. When considering the first question in Martin, (Did the lawyer receive confidential information attributable to a solicitor and client relationship relevant to the matter at hand?) the motions judge held that the law firm had received confidential information. However, the motions judge did not ask itself whether the lawyer had received confidential information. Instead, it attributed the law firm's confidential information to the solicitor by applying an inference that lawyers share confidences amongst one another, and that measures protecting against the misuse of confidential information had not been implemented. The Federal Court of Appeal concluded that the motions judge should not have resorted to the inference. However, there was evidence before it showing that the solicitor had received confidential information of Valeant's predecessor when he was at the law firm. He had reviewed confidential information of the predecessor pertaining to the same medicinal ingredient and the same patent in issue in the Cobalt notice of allegation. On the second Martin question—whether there was a risk that the confidential information held by the solicitor would be used to prejudice Valeant in the application—the solicitor had confidential information and so his disqualification was automatic. It followed that there were no grounds to set aside the Federal Court's order disqualifying the solicitor.[190]

The motions judge refused to declare the notice of allegation invalid because it believed that it lacked jurisdiction to grant it. It relied upon the court's decision in Pharmacia Inc. The Federal Court of Appeal agreed that Pharmacia Inc. was distinguishable. A motion for disqualification is something that the court can always consider. As a remedy on the motion in this case, Valeant sought a declaration that the product of a conflict of interest, the notice of allegation, be declared to be invalid. The real issue was whether that remedy could and should be granted to redress the conflict of interest. The Federal Court of Appeal concluded that it should not be granted and also went further and concluded that it could not be granted. The Federal Court of Appeal was not persuaded that the notice of allegation was the product of the misuse of information and an improper conflict of interest. There was no evidence that Valeant's confidential information was actually used in the preparation of the notice of allegation. There were only speculations and inferences. Much of the notice of allegation appeared to be based on facts that were objectively known and discoverable, and matters of law. This was not to say that confidential information was not misused but the court was not persuaded one way or the other. Even if could be found that confidential information was misused, it was impossible to know the extent to which confidential information was used in preparing the notice of allegation. In the circumstances, a declaration that the notice of allegation was invalid might be a remedy that overshoots the mark. The record was a paper record, not the sort of full record that would be created in an action for breach of fiduciary duty or misuse of confidential information—a proceeding that would have the advantage of full discovery and trial.[191]

The Federal Court of Appeal observed that neither Martin nor McKercher suggest or even hint that motions for disqualification can be used to redress actual misuses of confidential information and take the place of actions for breach of fiduciary duty and misuse of confidential information—actions that are tried on the basis of the advantages and protections associated with full discovery and trial. Indeed, in Martin the Supreme Court noted that “the use of confidential information” is “usually not susceptible of proof” on a motion such as this. The court left open whether there might be an exceptional case where the court's plenary power to redress an abuse of process might be triggered and justify the sort of additional relief sought.[192]

A relationship where a solicitor practiced in association with his father, gave certain advice from time to time in connection with land transactions, gave specific advice with respect to the particular transaction in issue, and attended at the meeting with the Rural Municipality in which it is alleged that certain confidential information was divulged was found to be sufficient to found a cause of action alleging a fiduciary duty and breach of that duty. In Franklin Land Development Ltd. v. Clements,[193] the issue arose in the context of an application for damages sought by the appellants against David Clements, Ross Clements, and Clements and Smith Barristers & Solicitors arising out of a land transaction involving the appellants. The appellants alleged that David Clements and Ross Clements, in their capacities as barristers and solicitors, owed a fiduciary obligation to them in connection with this transaction and that they breached that fiduciary duty and obligation by disclosing certain confidential information to the vendor and to the Rural Municipality. The Chambers judge erred in striking out the statement of claim against Ross Clements for a breach of a fiduciary duty and obligation owed to the appellants and particularly in stating that the fact that Ross Clements was the son of David Clements and practiced law in association with his father and had some knowledge of the business venture was not a sufficient legal or factual foundation to include him as a defendant. There was no information on which the Court of Appeal could conclude that the action was scandalous or vexatious.[194]

It is important to bear in mind that the efficacy of ethical walls is a question of fact. In Dataco Utility Services Ltd. v. Olameter Inc.,[195] a purchase transaction did not proceed and the defendant was successful in outbidding the plaintiff for a contract with a corporation that had been the major client of the plaintiff. During the RFP process for that contract, a memorandum entitled “Ethical Wall Procedures” was circulated to various employees of the defendant. That memorandum stated that the defendant intended “to adopt procedures to ensure that no information that may be confidential to the plaintiff that was obtained as a result of prior discussions was used in any way in connection with the defendant's bid.” The trial judge observed that, while they are by no means a panacea, it would be wrong to hold that measures such as ethical walls are never effective or that they must be in place by a designated time in order to be effective. Each case must be decided on its own facts.[196]

In British Columbia v. Imperial Tobacco Canada Ltd.,[197] the defendant tobacco companies applied to disqualify the law firm CFMM from representing the Province in its action to recover tobacco-related health care costs. In May 2013, the defendants were advised that the national consortium intended to retain CFMM as “local counsel.” One of the partners who joined the firm in 2005 had worked under contract with firms representing some of the defendants and was directly involved in preparing the defence between 1998 and 2000 and again between 2003 and 2005. Discussions about CFMM being retained to act for the Province began in January and February 2013. The firm had still not been retained but a number of steps were taken to create an information barrier or firewall between the partner and the rest of the firm with regard to the litigation. The immediate steps included: creation of password protected electronic files and modified email access so that the partner had no access to any files or emails relating to this litigation; establishment of a dedicated, password protected server for the litigation, which the partner could not access; conversion of CFMM's old server room to a dedicated room for the litigation that the partner could not access, with a separate printer, scanner, etc.; and agreeing to arrange separate premises for the work on this litigation if the firm was retained.[198]

The presumption that courts should draw an inference of confidences being shared “unless satisfied … that all reasonable measures have been taken to ensure that no disclosure will occur by the ‘tainted’ lawyer to the member or members of the firm who are engaged against the former client.” is not called for when the conflict only arises many years after the lawyer joins the firm. As long as no one at CFMM was involved in litigation against the partner's former clients, the firm had no interest in or possible benefit from receiving confidential information. The court observed that there was no reason for the litigation to be the subject of the kind of conversation in which intentional or inadvertent disclosure was likely to occur, stating:

… The circumstances giving rise to the heightened risk of disclosure or public perception of conflict referred to in Martin simply did not exist until CFMM was approached about acting for the Province, at which point immediate steps were taken to put in place the measures called for by Martin and Law Society.

The effect of the defendants' argument would be to make the inference of disclosure created by Martin irrebuttable when the conflict only comes into existence after the lawyer joins the firm. If affidavits and undertakings are not sufficient, the burden on the firm to show concrete steps to protect confidentiality would be impossible to meet because there had been no need for them in the absence of a conflict. In my view, nothing in Martin goes that far. It would be anomalous to have a presumption that is rebuttable in the face of an actual conflict, but irrebuttable before the conflict exists.[199]

The issue was whether there was a risk of confidential information being used to the prejudice of the defendants. The mere presence of the material in boxes and the partner's office or staff accessing the boxes on one occasion for an unrelated purpose did not amount to a sharing of confidential information or create a risk of misuse of that information. The court is concerned about the possibility of real mischief and not mischief that is speculative or theoretical.[200]

In Business Development Bank of Canada v. Interline Motor Freight Inc.,[201] the personal defendant applied to have the law firm removed as counsel for the plaintiff. The plaintiff's claim was against the defendant Interline for moneys advanced to it pursuant to certain loan agreements. The claim against the personal defendants was pursuant to the guarantees they provided to the plaintiff in relation to Interline's borrowings. The alleged confidential information that formed the basis of the defendants' concern was contained in statutory declarations pertaining to assets and liabilities provided to the law firm in November 2011.[202]

The solicitor was a partner at the law firm. He opened a file on November 4, 2011, for Interline and Harmon Bal. He was retained to act for them in connection with claims made by the Bank of Montreal. The claims included allegations of fraud. No other lawyer at the law firm acted in any capacity in connection with the BMO Fraud Action. The solicitor was not retained to act for either of the personal defendants in this action. He was made aware, however, by Harmon Bal that BMO had made claims against them in other proceedings. The solicitor did meet the personal defendant on at least two occasions in connection with the BMO matters. He may also have spoken to him on the telephone. He received instructions from Harmon Bal regarding the BMO matters and gave legal advice to him, which included a forbearance agreement as part of proposed terms of settlement. The personal defendant participated in those discussions. On December 22, 2011, he closed his file for all purposes and did not act for Interline or Harmon Bal, or anyone else in connection with the BMO matters, after that date. In June 2012, the solicitor's paper file was packaged and removed to secure storage. The solicitor first learned about BDC's involvement on November 30, 2012. He was advised by his partner that Harmon Bal had asserted in court that day, for the first time, that the law firm was in a potential conflict due to prior representation in connection with the BMO matters. He did not discuss his earlier representation with Mr. Fitzpatrick except to say it related to fraud and debt claims made by BMO and had nothing to do with BDC. Although the solicitor did not have any confidential information to impart, the law firm instituted a “firewall” to ensure that any information he did have relating to the BMO matters was not imparted to anyone else at the law firm.[203]

There may be cases in which a simple description of the two retainers shows them to be so closely connected that the court will infer the possible misuse of confidential information and thus find the retainers to be sufficiently related. It is for the client to demonstrate that the possibility of relevant confidential information having been acquired is realistic, not just theoretical. Given the drastic nature of the remedy, there should be compelling and cogent evidence which provides a sufficient connectiveness between the partners. For the purposes of its analysis, the court assumed that the solicitor obtained statutory declarations from the personal defendants and Harmon Bal pertaining to their respective assets and liabilities in November 2011 and that copies of those statutory declarations were in the closed file.[204]

The personal defendants had done no more than make a bald assertion that the BMO and BDC matters were sufficiently related. The two matters were unrelated because the solicitor acted for Harmon Bal who was not a party to the action and for Interline. While Interline was a party to the action, no relief was sought against it at the application for summary judgment. The solicitor's involvement was in relation to a matter involving a different creditor than BDC. The personal financial information communicated to the law firm by the personal defendants and Harmon Bal in November 2011 did not make the BMO and the BDC matters sufficiently connected or related.[205]

If the defendants had established that the BMO and BDC matters were sufficiently related, then a rebuttable presumption would have arisen that confidential information had passed to the respondent on this application, being BDC. The burden was then on BDC to satisfy the court that no relevant confidential information had been passed to it by the law firm. The confidential information related to the statutory declarations provided in connection to settlement discussions with BMO. The defendants' material did not suggest that there had been any improper use or transmission of privileged or confidential communications prior to the application for summary judgment. The affidavits of the solicitors established there had been no transmission of any confidential or relevant information to the other members of the law firm. Accordingly, the presumption confidential information was passed to BDC by the law firm had been rebutted. Additionally, there was no risk the confidential information would be misused in the future. The physical file was closed and moved to secure storage in June 2012. The “firewall” would continue to preclude any information whatsoever in relation to the previous retainer from being accessed by anyone at the law firm with the exception of the solicitor and his assistant. The law firm had established that a reasonably informed person would conclude that conveyance of relevant confidential information had not and would not occur.[206]

Moreover, as judgment had now been obtained against the personal defendants by BDC, even if BDC were obliged to retain different counsel than the law firm, the statutory declarations in relation to the proposed BMO forbearance agreement might well be producible to BDC in any event in proceedings in aid of execution.[207]

Where the privacy act in question explicitly permits the Commissioner to abrogate a claim of solicitor client privilege to verify whether documents are covered by solicitor client privilege, the Commissioner may review the documents to determine whether they are privileged and should therefore not be disclosed.[208]

In McColl v. Thompson,[209] the pleadings alleged that the personal plaintiff and the defendant negotiated over several months for the personal plaintiff to acquire part or all of the defendant's company. In the course of the negotiations, the plaintiff obtained confidential information about the defendant's companies. The negotiations broke down and the plaintiff retained the solicitor and his law firms to take action against the defendants, and the notice of civil claim was filed alleging fraudulent misrepresentation, conspiracy, passing off and breach of confidence. The defendants filed a counterclaim against the solicitor and his law corporation and law firm alleging they received confidential information from the plaintiffs about the defendants and that they had or would misuse it. It was asserted by the defendants that the solicitor deliberately and needlessly pled details of the defendants' confidential information for the purpose of conveying that information which amounted to an abuse of process. It was also alleged that the solicitor owed a duty of confidentiality and a duty to avoid conflict to the defendants.[210]
The statutory third party's motion for an order removing plaintiffs' counsel as lawyers of record on the basis of an alleged conflict of interest was dismissed in Mohammad v. Rasul.[211]

The action involved a claim for damages for personal injury and Family Law Act claims resulting from a single vehicle accident. The plaintiff was a passenger in the vehicle driven by the defendant which left the roadway and went into a ditch. The plaintiff claimed to have been injured in the accident and sought damages for the negligence of her husband in operating the vehicle. The defendant was insured with a Gore Mutual automobile insurance policy. The defendant refused to cooperate with Gore Mutual, including a refusal to provide a statement, and accordingly Gore Mutual claimed a breach of statutory condition and denied insurance coverage.
