As it was permitted to do under section 258(14) of the Insurance Act, Gore Mutual obtained an order adding it as a statutory third party to the action, which entitled Gore Mutual to defend the action as to liability, quantum and to participate in examinations for discovery and other aspects of the action. Thereafter, the plaintiffs obtained an order adding the Township as a defendant for allegedly failing to maintain the roadway in a fit condition, and obtained an order adding Gore Mutual as a party defendant on the basis of claimed coverage for damages resulting from the negligence of the driver of an uninsured, underinsured or unidentified motor vehicle.[212]

The moving party alleged seven steps within the action which, viewed cumulatively, demonstrated a conflict of interest such as to warrant removal of plaintiffs' counsel from the action. The seven steps were summarized as: (i) that plaintiffs' counsel gave legal advice to an unrepresented litigant who was opposed in interest; (ii) plaintiffs' counsel acted for the unrepresented litigant opposed in interest by objecting to questions on his behalf; (iii) plaintiffs' counsel met with the defendant and other family members behind closed doors during a recess in his examination for discovery; (iv) plaintiffs' counsel failed to send the plaintiffs for independent legal advice in response to the motion alleging a conflict of interest; (v) in response to the motion, counsel for the plaintiffs drafted their affidavits, and in a manner designed to support the position of counsel rather than accurately reflecting the position of the affiants; (vi) on cross-examination of one of the affidavits filed in response to the motion, plaintiffs' counsel sought to give evidence in support of her own position in re-examination of her affiant; and (vii) plaintiffs' counsel refused to produce copies of written waivers of conflict of interest allegedly signed by the plaintiffs.[213]

The defendant was examined for discovery utilizing a Dari/English interpreter. Counsel for the plaintiffs asked 147 questions and then indicated in response to the statement by counsel for the Township that she was going to ask the defendant a few questions: “Before, I'm sorry, before she goes ahead I know you're unrepresented but I just wanted to let you know that she today doesn't have the right to ask you questions so you may refuse any questions she asks you”. The lawyers then debated whether Township counsel had the right to ask questions, without resolving the issue, but Township counsel proceeded to ask the questions and the defendant answered.[214]

Justice Glithero was of the view that counsel have an obligation to provide procedural advice to unrepresented parties in such a situation as this. For instance, if an unrepresented litigant started to simply guess by way of answers to questions, or agreed to undertake to obtain information that was not his or her responsibility to obtain, Justice Glithero would expect counsel to step up and advise the examinee of his rights. The interjection by plaintiffs' counsel in the instance did not constitute the provision of legal advice to a litigant opposed in interest in any objectionable sense, at least when viewed on its own.[215]

During the examination by Township counsel of the defendant, the parties took a break. Shortly after the break Township counsel asked the defendant if he was in the other room with his wife's lawyer during the break and he answered that he was with his daughter and his grandchild. When asked if his wife's lawyer was in the room as well, he agreed that she was. Township counsel then asked “What was discussed”. Plaintiffs' counsel indicated on the record that she was in the other room meeting with her clients and did not want the defendant to disclose any information because it might be a matter of solicitor-client privilege. Township counsel observed that it wasn't privileged if the defendant had heard it. Township counsel asked her question again and plaintiffs' counsel interjected that the defendant would not have been able to understand what she would say in English.[216]

The onus of establishing a conflict of interest is on the moving party. In Justice Glithero's opinion, it had not been shown that plaintiffs' counsel also acted for the defendant. The fact that plaintiffs' counsel pointed out to the defendant that in her opinion he did not have to answer questions could not be said to amount to a solicitor-client relationship or justify a finding that she was acting as his counsel. She stated her opinion that he didn't have to answer questions if he didn't want to. He chose to and did, thereby ignoring her advice. Justice Glithero could not assume that the lawyer sought or obtained any information from the defendant in the closed door meeting room. As there was a denial of any information passing between the defendant and counsel, a mere unfounded suspicion that something may have been said can hardly amount to a “substantial risk” that it would be used to the detriment of the client.[217]

In Justice Glithero's opinion the moving party had not demonstrated a conflict of interest, either when the specific complaints were viewed individually, or collectively. Justice Glithero was of the view that pointing out to the unrepresented defendant counsel's view he didn't have to answer questions was not providing legal advice in a fashion that would create a solicitor and client relationship with a person opposite in interest. Justice Glithero was also of the view that plaintiffs' counsel's objection to questions to the unrepresented defendant as to what was said during the closed door meeting were legitimate attempts to protect her clients' solicitor-client privilege, and was not a situation of objecting to a question on behalf of the unrepresented litigant such as to lead to a fair conclusion that counsel was acting as counsel for him. As to the closed door meeting, there had been no demonstrated risk for misuse of confidential information as there was no evidence that any confidential information was imparted.[218]

Justice Glithero explained that if there was no conflict of interest, then the further complaints about the absence of independent legal advice and the apparent lack of clear understanding about the meaning of that term or of the meaning conflict of interest were not enough to create a conflict of interest where none arose on the facts concerning the interactions between the parties. It would have been better if counsel for the plaintiffs had not drafted the affidavits filed on the motion, it would be better if more efforts had been made to have the plaintiffs get independent legal advice, and would have been better to furnish counsel for the moving party with the written authorizations to continue to represent the plaintiffs. These additional matters related to what could have been done to remedy a conflict of interest, or to overcome it in a way such as to enable plaintiffs' counsel to continue to act in spite of the conflict of interest. But, Justice Glithero had concluded that there was no conflict of interest.[219]

Justice Glithero observed that it is trite law to indicate that counsel of choice is an important legal concept and not one to be interfered with lightly. In the absence of a proven conflict of interest, there were no grounds to remove plaintiffs' counsel from the record.[220]

Within the overall test propounded in McDonald Estate v. Martin, Justice Glithero was satisfied that a reasonably informed person, apprised of the circumstances, would be satisfied that no confidential information was received by the lawyer from the unrepresented litigant, and that there was no risk that anything was said by the client which could be used to his prejudice. The possibility of misuse of confidential information must be realistic and not merely theoretical. As indicated in Best v. Cox, 2013 CarswellOnt 18839, 2013 ONCA 695, “Canadian courts exercise the highest level of restraint before interfering with a party's choice of counsel. Where such discretionary, equitable relief is invoked, there must be a possible or real mischief should a removal order be refused. The test is whether a fair minded and reasonably informed member of the public would conclude that counsel's removal is necessary for the proper administration of justice.” Justice Glithero was of the opinion that this mythical, fair minded and reasonably informed member of the public might very well shake his or her head in disapproval of what transpired in the impugned examination for discovery, but would not conclude that the removal of counsel was necessary in the circumstances.[221]

With respect to the communication of confidential information by the plaintiffs to the solicitor and his use of it, including incorporating the notice of civil claim, obviously any client with any confidential information from another party with whom litigation is about to commence must be able to convey that confidential information to their lawyer of choice, and that lawyer must be able to receive it and use it in the litigation without fear of suit by the opposing party whose information it was. To conclude otherwise would be to put at risk any lawyer who ever received another parties' confidential information from a client. Further, the doctrine of absolute immunity applied. An absolute privilege attaches to the pleadings and they may not form the basis for a cause of action, even for abuse of process. The privilege extends to statements made in court, the evidence of witnesses, to submissions, to addresses, to statements made in court by counsel, and to pleadings.[222]

With regard to the allegations in the counterclaim that the solicitor owed duties of confidentiality or duties to avoid conflicts of interest to the defendants, and that he had breached the same, the defendants provided no case authorities to support the proposition that a lawyer owes duties to an opposing party in litigation. The counterclaim was ordered struck with leave to the defendants to re-file as against the plaintiffs.[223]

With respect to the communication of confidential information to a solicitor and its use in pleadings, a different view was expressed in Irving Oil Ltd. v. Ashar[224] where the employee prior to commencing employment with Fort Reliance Company Limited, an affiliate of Irving Oil, signed a confidentiality and non-competition agreement wherein he agreed to at all times hold all Confidential Information in trust for Fort Alliance in the strictest confidence. He agreed he would not disclose or in any manner communicate any Confidential Information except to the extent necessary to enable himself to properly perform his permitted activities. The agreement provided that information from part of the public domain could not be deemed to be Confidential Information.[225]

The employee resigned from all positions with the Irving group of companies. He subsequently claimed to be entitled to an additional $25 million from Irving Oil and said if his demands were not met by a specified date that he would commence an action against Irving Oil. The employee stated that in the event of a Statement of Claim being filed it would become a public record and thereby be available to the media. After the Statement of Claim was filed, he would answer, subject to his confidentiality obligations, the media's questions relating to why he commenced to legal proceedings against Irving Oil and why he believed he had not been compensated fairly with respect to the increase in the equity value of Irving Oil.[226]

In response to the employee's letter, an application was granted that prohibited the employee from breaching his confidentiality to Irving Oil prohibiting the employee from “directly or indirectly disclosing any of Irving Oil's or any of its affiliate's confidential information in breach of either 1 (i) the confidentiality agreement; or 2 (ii) his fiduciary duties owed to Irving Oil. The motions judge described the letter as a “not so thinly veiled threat to attempt to cause highly Confidential Information relating to Irving Oil and to the members of the Irving family to be made available to the media and to the public if the plaintiff is quote ‘forced to do so’.”[227]

A Statement of Claim was issued in the New Brunswick Court of Queen's Bench. The employer alleged that paragraph 23 described information that was protected as Confidential Information. Paragraph 23 of Statement of Claim stated:

During 2012 and the first few months of 2013, there were many instances of misconduct and inappropriate behaviour involving members of the Irving family that created an intolerable and poisoned work environment for Mr. Ashar. As a result, Mr. Ashar was constructively dismissed. Mr. Ashar informed Irving Oil in early 2013 that he would be prepared to leave Irving Oil earlier than his scheduled departure date of December 31, 2013 on mutually agreeable terms. After many meetings and discussions, Mr. Ashar and Irving Oil agreed that Mr. Ashar would stop reporting to work but remain on the Irving Oil payroll and continue to be paid his regular salary and continue to receive all of his normal benefits until December 31, 2013.[228]

The motions judge concluded that the impugned paragraph of the Statement of Claim offended both the language and the spirit of the order prohibiting the employee from “directly or indirectly” disclosing any of Irving Oil's or any of its affiliate's confidential information in breach of either of either 1 (i) the confidentiality agreement; or 2 (ii) his fiduciary duties owed to Irving Oil, stating:

What must be borne in mind is that during 2012/2013 period of time, Mr. Ashar was the President of the company and a Director. One must assume that in that position, in the normal course of his duties, he would become privy to information which could well be embarrassing for the Irving family or it's corporations. It may be that there was inappropriate conduct of which he became aware. Certainty this has been alleged.

If Mr. Ashar came by this information, in any manner, by virtue of his position, he may not disclose it to anyone, let alone to the world by the filing of Statement of Claim. Not only does Mr. Ashar have an obligation by way of agreement, he also has a fiduciary duty to his company and its family members. Among such duties would be, in my respectful view, the duty not to embarrass any family member and to not disclose any information about possible inappropriate conduct, so long as he came into that information by virtue of carrying out his duty as a President and as a Director.

Mr. Ashar was, as the President of the company, a confidant to members of the Irving family. As such he would, certainly could, have received information which might be embarrassing for the family. This is clearly not information that is in the public domain. Even if Mr. Ashar felt compelled to disclose such information because of a sense of moral obligation or simply corporate duty, he has promised to not disclose it unless required by law to do so. And then, only by following the terms of the agreement.[229]

The motions judge concluded that this was nothing more than attempt to embarrass the family and to exert pressure upon them to pay a sum of money that he felt he was owed. There had been a deliberate flaunting of an Order done with full knowledge of the terms of that Order. The motions judge observed that he had no jurisdiction over the New Brunswick Court of Queen's Bench and would not purport in any manner to interfere with what had taken place there. The Plaintiff had options within that jurisdiction. An Order was issued declaring that Ashar and his solicitor breached the order.[230]

The appellant in Irving Oil Ltd. v. Ashar[231] appealed both the Injunction Order and the Contempt Order. The Court of Appeal concluded that there was no basis for appellate interference with the Injunction Order as originally granted. However, recent events had superseded any need for the Alberta courts to supervise the conduct of these parties or their underlying litigation, and the Injunction Order was therefore now set aside. With respect to the second appeal, there was no basis on which the appellant or his counsel could be found in contempt of the Injunction Order, and the appeal from the Contempt Order was allowed.[232]

The tripartite test was applicable to the injunction application before the chambers judge. The relief sought was in the nature of quia timet relief, based on a fear of prospective irreparable harm. A higher standard typically applies to such relief; there must be a high probability that the harm will occur and an element of an “imminent and real” threat. In this case, the chambers judge seems to have considered the appellant's letter such a threat. The Chambers judge did not exercise his discretion unreasonably in coming to that conclusion.[233]

The chambers judge also concluded that the disclosure of confidential information by the appellant could not be adequately compensated in damages, and would lead to irreparable harm. Where an applicant seeks to enjoin a breach of confidence, it can be easier to establish the need for injunctive relief. However, an application for injunctive relief also requires that the court weigh the benefit of the injunction for the applicant against the cost it will impose upon the respondent. There was nothing on the record to indicate that the chambers judge considered the cost on the appellant at all. The balance of convenience required a nuanced approach. An injunction prohibiting the appellant from following through on a perceived threat to disclose confidential information may have been warranted. An injunction preventing his access to the courts by restricting his ability to file pleadings would have failed to properly strike that balance. The Court of Appeal did not read the injunction granted as going that far. Although the chambers judge erred in failing to consider the balance of convenience, the language of the injunction as ordered did not impose an undue burden on the appellant.[234]

The real difficulty arose with the chambers judge's interpretation and application of his Injunction Order. He held that the vague allegations of “misconduct and inappropriate behaviour” that created “an intolerable and poisoned work environment”, as set out in paragraph 23 of the Statement of Claim, breached the language and the spirit of that earlier order. Allegations of misconduct amounting to constructive dismissal are not the type of “confidential information” that the Confidentiality Agreement was intended to protect. Clause 1.1 of the Agreement defines “confidential information” as including various types of business documents and data, “which is the property of” Irving or its affiliates. Nor was it the type of information that the Injunction Order was seemingly granted to protect. In his reasons for granting that Order, the chambers judge noted that he was not concerned as much with potentially embarrassing information, but rather with “information which competitor companies may well seek to use to their advantage and to the disadvantage of the plaintiff”. Paragraph 23 contained no such information. Paragraph 23 contained allegations of misconduct in the vaguest of terms. It was difficult to see how the appellant could have made the statements any more vague and still set out a claim. Only an order that enjoined the plaintiff from filing pleadings at all could have captured this paragraph, and an order preventing access to the courts in that way would not have been appropriate. Confidential information may well be relevant in the continuing New Brunswick litigation and may have to be disclosed there, but that is for the parties and the New Brunswick courts to address. It does not render the language of paragraph 23 contemptuous of the Injunction Order.[235]

In Noseworthy v. Noseworthy,[236] the husband filed an interlocutory application in a family proceeding seeking to have the solicitor disqualified from further representation of the wife based upon the husband's concern that financial information provided in the family proceeding might be used by the solicitor in his defamation proceeding against the husband. The solicitor had not represented the husband. His client was only the wife who, after separation, has claimed against the husband based upon their marital relationship and the resulting legal consequences flowing from their separation.[237]

The court was not prepared to find that the husband was a client or “near client” of the solicitor. For the “near client” circumstance to arise, it must be found that there was a previous relationship, not only between the lawyer and the client but also between a person involved or associated with the client in connection with the original matter which is sufficiently related to the retainer from which it is sought to remove the solicitor to justify the removal. While the husband no doubt had been involved with or associated with the wife due to their marital relationship, that involvement or association never included any form of a solicitor/client relationship as required in order to engage either a client or “near client” consideration for removal on the basis of conflict of interest. Therefore, any concern regarding communication of confidential information in circumstances creating an expectation of privacy or confidentiality did not arise in the circumstances as between the husband and the solicitor. While disqualification of counsel can occur in some circumstances where there has not been a direct solicitor/client relationship, specifically for the “near client”, those circumstances did not exist based upon any conflict of interest due to possible misuse of confidential information imparted in a solicitor/client or “near client” situation.[238]

An argument was made that as financial disclosure obtained in family proceedings has some confidentiality protection, the solicitor had been using the family law proceeding to request financial disclosure that would benefit him in his civil claim as against the husband. Thus it was alleged that he would misuse what is to be confidential information. It was suggested that the solicitor had been seeking financial disclosure in the family proceeding that was irrelevant and unnecessary to conclude that proceeding and his reason for doing this was to support enforcement of a judgment he might receive in his civil claim against the husband. The court concluded that there had been no improper financial disclosure requested by the wife in the family law proceeding. Extensive financial disclosure from the husband was both relevant and necessary in this family case. There was no realistic potential or necessity for the solicitor to obtain or use any financial disclosure provided in the family proceedings to assist him in his defamation claim. The enforcement of a civil judgment could occur without reference to information that was obtained in the family law proceeding. As a result, that there had not been any possible misuse of confidential information by the solicitor or any reasonable potential for such to occur in future that would support a disqualification order in this case.[239]

As a consequence of a prior relationship with O, the applicants in Terceira v. LIUNA[240] asked that the Vice-Chair recuse himself from hearing the application About seven years earlier, when the Vice-Chair was a member of the Bar, he had acted for O. The earlier matter involving O concerned his employment with Local 183 or related entities. The applicants asserted that O's employment was an issue in the current application and that the Vice-Chair's prior representation of him gave rise to possible conflicts, both in terms of his knowledge of Mr. O'Brien's employment history with Local 183 and the possibility that the Vice-Chair might wind up as a witness on the current application if it was permitted to proceed. The Vice-Chair declined to recuse himself. In so doing, the Vice-Chair said that he had no present recollection of the facts surrounding his earlier representation of O. In allowing the application, the court observed that the Vice-Chair could not establish that no information was imparted which could be relevant since, on his own admission, he had no recollection of the earlier matter. The Vice-Chair did not seem to have considered that hearing evidence relating to his former client might, at some point in the future, trigger memories of information imparted to him by his former client.[241]

On the appeal in Terceira v. LIUNA,[242] the respondents agreed that the Divisional Court applied the incorrect test but submitted that the correct test yielded the right result and that the OLRB decisions were properly quashed. The Court of Appeal set aside the decisions of the Divisional Court disqualifying the Vice-Chair. It was accepted by all parties that the test set forth in Wewaykum was applicable and not that in MacDonald Estate. Courts, as well as the OLRB, have consistently applied a reasonable apprehension of bias test to address adjudicators' prior professional relationships. The distinction between a claim of conflict of interest by a lawyer and reasonable apprehension of bias by an adjudicator is significant for a number of reasons. In MacDonald Estate, which addresses a lawyer's potential conflict of interest, the Supreme Court found, at p. 1260, that the imparting of confidential information is presumed to occur. In contrast, in Wewaykum, which addresses a claim of reasonable apprehension of bias of an adjudicator, the Supreme Court of Canada established that impartiality of the adjudicator is presumed. Indeed, there is a strong presumption of judicial or adjudicative impartiality and integrity. The rules governing a lawyer's conflict of interest stem, in part, from the existence of a fiduciary relationship and a duty of loyalty owed to the client. In contrast, the adjudicator's duty is anchored in principles of procedural fairness including impartiality. The distinction has important implications for the OLRB administrative function. In selecting its adjudicators, the OLRB draws upon the expertise of practitioners from within the labour and employment bar. A presumption of disqualification would operate to disregard this practical reality. By applying the incorrect test, the Divisional Court failed to apply the presumption of impartiality. The Divisional Court also failed to conduct a contextual analysis, which required consideration of a number of factors that are relevant to the reasonable apprehension of bias test. The inquiry into an allegation of apprehension of bias by an adjudicator is “highly fact-specific” and is evaluated on an objective standard. The person considering the alleged bias must be reasonable and the apprehension of bias must be reasonable. To succeed, the Employees would have to establish that reasonable, right-minded and properly informed persons would think that the Vice-Chair was consciously or unconsciously influenced by his participation, about seven years earlier, in a matter resolved at the pleadings stage and of which the Vice-Chair said he had no knowledge of any parts material to the proceeding before him.[243]

The Employees failed to rebut the presumption of impartiality that attached to the Vice-Chair. The proceeding before the Vice-Chair was a hearing dealing with preliminary motions submitted by LIUNA and Local 183 and, as such, was limited in scope. O's length of service with an entity related to Local 183, if relevant at all, was only germane to the remedial stage of the Application. This was not before the Vice-Chair. No materials or record of any kind were filed in support of a claim of reasonable apprehension of bias. O's retainer ended about seven years prior and settled at the pleadings stage. It did not include unfair labour practice complaints against LIUNA or Local 183. Examined objectively, there was an inadequate nexus between the factual matrix before the Vice-Chair and the prior retainer by O'. An adjudicator's statement that “he or she knew nothing about the case and had no involvement in it will ordinarily be accepted at face value unless there is good reason to doubt it.”[244]

In Ibrahim v. MacInnis et al.,[245] the solicitor and law firm applied to strike the claimant's claim. In 2011, the plaintiff met with the solicitor in relation to two matters. Over a period of six weeks in June to July 2015, the plaintiff had discussions with the solicitor and provided information about his claims to the solicitor. Ultimately, the solicitor was not retained by the plaintiff. The plaintiff alleged that he provided the defendants with confidential information and that the solicitor disclosed this information to a client that the solicitor acted for, namely Legacy, a law firm being sued by the plaintiff in separate proceedings in the B.C. Supreme Court. The plaintiff acknowledged that he had no direct evidence that the solicitor disclosed any confidential information. He argued though that he should be entitled to a trial where he could question the solicitor to uncover evidence.[246]

The claim against Legacy arose out of extradition proceedings being brought against the plaintiff by the Attorney General of Canada on behalf of the United States Government. The Court upheld the extradition application and ordered that the plaintiff be detained. The plaintiff commenced a B.C. Supreme Court action against Legacy alleging that he retained a lawyer with Legacy to provide an expert opinion for use in the plaintiff's extradition proceedings but that the affidavit was not provided and that the expert opinion letter itself could not be used at the hearing. Legacy retained the solicitor to act on their behalf as legal counsel to defend the action. The claim against Legacy had essentially sat dormant for years.[247]

The judge observed that there was a valid basis to suspect that the plaintiff was using the court action to dissuade the solicitor from representing Legacy but concluded that a suspicion alone was not a basis to find that an abuse of process existed. Counsel for the defendants referred to the Supreme Court of Canada decision in Wallace v. Canadian Pacific Railway, [2013] S.C.J. No. 39 (S.C.C.) in support of the proposition that a lawyer may be disqualified from acting for one party to a dispute if there is a breach of a duty of loyalty owed to the other party in the dispute. The judge did not read that decision as saying there cannot be a claim for damages against the lawyer if there is a breach of a duty of loyalty. In the Canadian National Railway Co. case, the only relief being sought was a disqualification and so there was no discussion of whether damages can also be sought against a disqualified lawyer. It concerned the Court that the plaintiff acknowledged that he had no evidence of any wrong doing on the part of the defendants. His hope was that at trial he would be able to cross-examine the solicitor in order to obtain the evidence that supported his claim. However, if the defendants elected to call no evidence, then the plaintiff might have nothing to support his claim. In those circumstances, proceeding to trial could be a waste of judicial resources. The plaintiff was not in a position to quantify his damages, if any. To succeed, the plaintiff would need to prove at a minimum that there was a disclosure of confidential information by the solicitor to Legacy and that this negatively affected his claim against Legacy, causing him a financial loss. The claim would fail or at best only result in a nominal award if the plaintiff could not prove any damages. In order to even attempt to assess a damage claim in this proceeding, the plaintiff needed to resolve the Legacy action. The judge would not order a dismissal of the case in relation to any alleged disclosure of confidential information to Legacy as it would be premature.[248]
